105.01 DIVISION OF CITY; BOUNDARIES GENERALLY.
   The City is hereby divided into four wards, bounded as provided in Sections
105.02 to
105.05. (Ord. 4433-14. Passed 11-18-14.)
 
105.02 FIRST WARD.
   The first ward of the City shall be composed of the territory lying and
being within the following described boundaries: beginning at the intersection
of the centerline of U.S. Route 68 and the southern corporation line; thence in
a northerly direction with the eastern and southern corporation boundary to the
intersection of the centerline of East Powell Avenue; thence in a westerly
direction along the centerline of East Powell Avenue to the intersection of the
centerline of U.S. Route 68 (also being known as Main Street); thence in a
northerly direction with the centerline of U.S. Route 68 to the intersection of
the Indiana and Ohio Railway, such railroad being the first set of tracks north
of Boyce Street; thence in a southwesterly direction with the centerline of the
Indiana and Ohio Railway to the intersection of the centerline of Gwynne
Street; thence in a westerly direction with the centerline of Gwynne Street, to
the western corporation line; thence with the western and southern corporation
lines to the place of beginning.
(Ord. 4433-14. Passed 11-18-14.)
 
105.03 SECOND WARD.
   The second ward of the City shall be composed of the territory lying and
being within the following described boundaries: beginning at the intersection
of the centerline of U.S. Route 68 (also being known as Main Street) and East
Powell Avenue; thence in a northerly direction with the centerline of U.S.
Route 68 to the intersection of the centerline of East Church Street; thence in
an easterly direction with the centerline of East Church Street to the
intersection of the centerline of East Lawn Avenue; thence in a southerly
direction with the centerline of East Lawn Avenue to the intersection of the
centerline of U.S. Route 36/State Route 29 (also known as Scioto Street in this
location); thence in an easterly direction with the centerline of U.S. Route 36
to the eastern corporation line; thence with the eastern and southern
corporation lines to the intersection of the centerline of East Powell Avenue;
thence in a westerly direction with the centerline of East Powell Avenue to the
place of beginning.
(Ord. 4433-14. Passed 11-18-14.)
 
105.04  THIRD WARD.
   The third ward of the City shall be composed of the territory lying and
being within the following described boundaries: beginning at the intersection
of the centerlines of U.S. Route 68 (also being known as Main Street) and East
Church Street; thence in a northerly direction with the centerline of U.S.
Route 68 to the centerline of the Indiana and Ohio Railway, such railroad being
the first set of tracks north of Boyce Street; thence with the centerline of
the Indiana and Ohio Railway prolonged in a northeasterly direction to the
northern corporation line; thence with the northern and eastern corporation
lines to the intersection of the centerline of U.S. Route 36; thence in a
westerly direction with the centerline of U.S. Route 36 to the intersection of
the centerline of East Lawn Avenue; thence in a northerly direction with the
centerline of East Lawn Avenue to the intersection of the centerline of East
Church Street; thence in a westerly direction with the centerline of East
Church Street to the place of beginning.
(Ord. 4433-14. Passed 11-18-14.)
 
105.05 FOURTH WARD.
   The fourth ward of the City shall be composed of the territory lying and
being within the following described boundaries: beginning at the intersection
of the centerline of Gwynne Street and the centerline of the Indiana and Ohio
Railway, such railroad being the only set of tracks underneath the Gwynne
Street Bridge; thence with the centerline of the Indiana and Ohio Railway
prolonged in a northeasterly direction to the northern corporation line; thence
with the northern and western corporation lines to the intersection of the
centerline of Gwynne Street; thence in an easterly direction with the
centerline of Gwynne Street to the place of beginning.
(Ord. 4433-14. Passed 11-18-14.)
 
 
CHAPTER 107
Open Meetings
 
 
107.01   Meetings of governmental bodies.
 
 
CROSS REFERENCES
         Open meetings - see CHTR. Sec.
2.07
         Open meeting law - see Ohio R.C. 121.22
 
 
107.01 MEETINGS OF GOVERNMENTAL BODIES.
   (a)   This section shall be liberally construed to require public officials
to take official action and to conduct all deliberations upon official business
only in open meetings, unless the subject matter is specifically excepted by
law.
 
   (b)   As used in this section:
      (1)   "Public body" means Council or any board, commission, committee,
agency or similar decision-making body of the City, but excluding the Board of
Control.
      (2)   "Meeting" means any prearranged discussion of the public business
of the public body by a majority of its members.
 
   (c)   Except as otherwise provided in subsection (e) hereof, all meetings of
any public body are declared to be public meetings open to the public at all
times. A member of a public body shall be present in person at a meeting open
to the public to be considered present or to vote at the meeting and for
purposes of determining whether a quorum is present at the meeting.
The minutes of a regular or special meeting of any such public body shall be
promptly recorded and open to public inspection. The minutes need only reflect
the general subject matter of discussions in executive sessions authorized
under subsection (e) hereof.
 
   (d)   Every public body shall, by rule, establish a reasonable method
whereby any person may determine the time and place, and purpose of all special
meetings. A public body shall not hold a special meeting unless it gives at
least twenty-four hours advance notice to the new media that have requested
notification, except in the event of an emergency requiring immediate official
action. In the event of an emergency, the member or members calling the meeting
shall notify the new media that have requested notification immediately of the
time, place and purpose of the meeting.
   The rule shall provide that any person may, upon request and payment of a
reasonable fee, obtain reasonable advance notification of all meetings at which
any specific type of public business is to be discussed. Provisions for advance
notification may include, but are not limited to, mailing the agenda of
meetings to all subscribers on a mailing list or mailing notices in self-
addressed, stamped envelopes provided by the person.
 
   (e)   The members of a public body may hold an executive session only after
a majority of a quorum of the public body determines, by a roll call vote, to
hold such a session and only at a regular or special meeting for the sole
purpose of the consideration of any of the following matters:
      (1)   To consider the appointment, employment, dismissal, discipline,
promotion, demotion or compensation of a public employee or official, or the
investigation of charges or complaints against a public employee, official or
licensee, unless the public employee, official or licensee requests a public
hearing. Except as otherwise provided by law, no public body shall hold an
executive session for the discipline of an elected official for conduct related
to the performance of his official duties or for his removal from office. If a
public body holds an executive session pursuant to this subsection, the motion
and vote to hold that executive session shall state which one or more of the
approved purposes listed in this subsection are the purposes for which the
executive session is to be held, but need not include the name of any person to
be considered at the meeting;
      (2)   To consider the purchase of property for public purposes, or for
the sale of property at competitive bidding, if premature disclosure of
information would give an unfair competitive or bargaining advantage to a
person whose personal, private interest is adverse to the general public
interest. No member of a public body shall use this subsection as a subterfuge
for providing covert information to prospective buyers or sellers. A purchase
or sale of public property is void if the seller or buyer of the public
property has received covert information from a member of a public body that
has not been disclosed to the general public in sufficient time for other
prospective buyers and sellers to prepare and submit offers. If the minutes of
the public body show that all meetings and deliberations of the public body
have been conducted in compliance with this section, any instrument executed by
the public body purporting to convey, lease or otherwise dispose of any right,
title or interest in any public property shall be conclusively presumed to have
been executed in compliance with this section insofar as title or other
interest of any bona fide purchasers, lessees or transferees of the property is
concerned;
      (3)   Conferences with an attorney for the public body concerning
disputes involving the public body that are the subject of pending or imminent
court action;
      (4)   Preparing for, conducting or reviewing negotiations or bargaining
sessions with public employees concerning their compensation or other terms and
conditions of their employment;
      (5)   Matters required to be kept confidential by federal law or rules or
state statutes;
      (6)   Specialized details of security arrangements where disclosure of
the matters discussed might reveal information that could be used for the
purpose of committing, or avoiding prosecution for, a violation of the law; and
      (7)   To discuss the recruitment, establishment, retention or expansion
of any private business.
   If a public body holds an executive session to consider any of the matters
listed in subsection (e)(2) to (7) hereof, the motion and vote to hold that
executive session shall state which one or more of the approved matters listed
in those divisions are to be considered at the executive session.
 
   (f)   A resolution, rule or formal action of any kind is invalid unless
adopted in an open meeting of the public body. A resolution, rule or formal
action adopted in an open meeting that results from deliberations in a meeting
not open to the public is invalid unless the deliberations were for a purpose
specifically authorized in subsection (e) hereof and conducted at an executive
session held in compliance with this section.
 
   (g)   (1)   Any person may bring an action to enforce the provisions of this
section. Upon proof of a violation or threatened violation of this section in
an action brought by any person, the Court of Common Pleas shall issue an
injunction to compel the members of the public body to comply with its
provisions.
      (2)   If the Court of Common Pleas issues an injunction pursuant to this
section, the Court may award to the party that sought the injunction all court
costs and reasonable attorney's fees and also shall order the public body that
it enjoins to pay a civil forfeiture of one hundred dollars ($100.00). If the
Court of Common Pleas does not issue an injunction pursuant to this section and
the Court determines at that time that the bringing of the action was frivolous
conduct as defined in Ohio R.C. 2323.51(A), the Court may award to the public
body all court costs and reasonable attorney's fees.
      (3)   Irreparable harm and prejudice to the party that sought the
injunction shall be conclusively and irrebuttably presumed upon proof of a
violation or threatened violation of this section.
      (4)   A member of a public body who knowingly violates an injunction
issued pursuant to this subsection may be removed from office by an action
brought in the Court of Common Pleas for that purpose by the Director of Law.
         (Ord. 3871. Passed 7-9-91.)

107.01
 
111.01 JOURNAL OF PROCEEDINGS; INDEX OF MINUTES.
   The Clerk of Council shall keep a regular and correct journal of the
proceedings of Council. She shall keep a full and complete index to the minutes
of Council, recorded by her in a book furnished to her by Council for such
purpose.
(1984 Code Sec. 31.70)
111.02 RULES.
   These rules are promulgated pursuant to Urbana Citv Charter Section
2.08 .
Preamble
These rules of procedure have been designed to address common questions of
Council Members as well as the general public. City Council, as the legislative
body, has powers as set forth in the Urbana City Charter exclusive to
legislation and appropriation.
Section 1 - Meetings
1.1 Organizational Meetings
   
   The Council shall meet annually in compliance with Urbana City Charter
Section
2.05 . At the annual meeting, each Council member may be assigned to one or
more committees by the President.
1.2 Regular Meetings/Quorum/Open Meetings
   The Council shall meet regularly in compliance with Urbana City Charter
Section
2.07 , with a quorum of at least four members to vote. As of 2015, the Council
shall meet the first and third Tuesday of each month at the Urbana Municipal
Building at 7:00 p.m. unless the schedule is adjusted by majority vote to avoid
conflicts with holidays, etc. All meetings of Council shall be held in
accordance with the general laws of Ohio pertaining to requirements for open
meetings of public bodies, Ohio R.C. 121.22.
1.3 Special Meetings/Work Sessions
   The Council may also hold special meetings in compliance with Urbana City
Charter Section
2.07 . These meetings are often termed "work sessions" for discussion or
information-gathering purposes, but on occasion a special meeting to take
action may be held due to deadlines for required action by Council on
legislation.
   Special meetings of Council may be called upon the written request of the
Mayor, or as scheduled during a regular meeting by the Council President or
consensus of any four members of Council. The Clerk may give notice of a work
session via e-mail, and work sessions are also open meetings.
1.4 Meeting Agendas
   The Clerk of Council will deliver the agenda for every meeting at least
three days prior to each regular meeting and at least one day prior to each
special meeting. Anyone desiring to introduce legislation for Council's
consideration shall deliver it to the Clerk by 4:00 p.m. on the Tuesday prior
to a regular meeting. Proposed legislation delivered after that deadline may be
placed on the agenda for the next subsequent Council meeting unless it is of an
emergency nature as determined by the Director of Law.
   The Clerk may deliver agendas to council members (and other City employees)
as PDF (portable document format) files via e-mail, post the digital PDF to the
City website, and shall print a sufficient number of hard copies for the public
in attendance at meetings.
1.5 Record of Meetings
   The Clerk shall use any available equipment to create an audio recording of
each Council meeting except for executive sessions. The Clerk shall prepare the
minutes as a summary of Council action and discussion.
   In the absence of the Clerk, the President shall call for votes as needed,
but the President Pro Tempore shall take written notes to assist the Clerk with
preparing meeting minutes, or else prepare the minutes if the Clerk is
unavailable to do so in a timely fashion. The Clerk may also designate a
different substitute with at least 48 hours notice to both the President and
President Pro Tempore for any planned absences.
Section 2 - Order of Business for Meetings
2.1 Call to Order. Roll Call. Pledge and Minutes
   The President (or President Pro Tempore) shall promptly call the meeting to
order at the appointed time and the Clerk shall call roll of all Council
Members present, followed by the Pledge of Allegiance. As the first order of
business, the Council shall review minutes of the most recent meetings as
prepared by the Clerk and recommend any corrections or changes before approval
of those minutes by voice vote.
2.2 Proclamations and Presentations
   Generally, the President and Council may accommodate the recitation of
ceremonial resolutions and proclamations (by the Council as a body, the Council
President, and/or the Mayor), as well as short presentations, such as the
"swearing in" of new City officials and employees, prior to or immediately
after the review of minutes as the first order of business. Resolutions of
congratulations, commendations, condolences, and the like, which are not of a
general and permanent nature, may be voted and acted upon immediately after one
reading pursuant to Urbana City Charter Section
2.10 .
2.3 Communications
   All general communications to the Council as a legislative body may be
scanned to a portable document format (PDF) and sent digitally by the Clerk via
e-mail along with the meeting agenda.
   Unless any specific communication requires additional discussion, the
communications may be accepted by consent agenda with a majority voice vote.
Any Council member may make a motion to remove an item from the consent agenda
for additional discussion without the need for a second. Any item removed from
the consent agenda, after discussion, requires a separate majority voice vote
for acceptance.
2.4 Administrative Reports
   Generally, Council action on administrative reports is limited to Board of
Control purchase items. Notes to the Board of Control report that are provided
for information only do not require action by ordinance, resolution or motion.
2.5 Public Comment and Questions
   (a)    Addressing Council: Time Limits
      The President shall recognize any members of the public who have signed
in to address Council at the allotted time unless specified otherwise in the
agenda. Members of the public must use the microphone at the podium and state
name and address for the minutes. Each member of the public has a time limit of
five minutes to address Council, unless granted an extension by motion and vote
of Council members or prior scheduling with the Clerk to be included on the
agenda.
   (b)    Public Questions and Answers on Issues Raised at Meetings
      The public comment period is not a question-and-answer or debate session.
For any issues outside the scope of Council's functions in legislation and
appropriation, the Council President may refer citizens to speak with the
administration or another appropriate City department and ask for a follow-up
report from the administration.
2.6. Legislation
   Council shall consider any ordinances or resolutions submitted for first
reading, then second reading, then third reading, unless the meeting agenda
specifies otherwise.
2.7 Department Liaison Reports
   Any Council member serving as a liaison to a Department or Departments of
the City shall provide updates to Council.
2.8 Miscellaneous Business
   The Council President may ask for miscellaneous business concerns from each
Council member, and then from each department head in "round-table" fashion
after legislative matters are concluded.
2.9 Executive Session
   Executive sessions shall generally be held at the end of regular meetings
unless a meeting agenda specifies otherwise. Every motion to enter executive
session must specify the reason pursuant to Ohio R.C. 121.22(g). Prior to
entering executive session, the Council President may advise whether any
additional discussion or action is anticipated after the conclusion of the
executive session for the public's benefit.
Section 3 - Legislative Procedure
3.1 Forms of Action by Council
   All actions of Council shall be by ordinance, resolution or motion. Motions
with majority voice vote shall be used to conduct the routine business of
Council, in procedural matters, for elections conducted among and appointments
made by Council members, to make requests of city officials, and as otherwise
provided in the City Charter. All other action shall be taken by ordinance or
resolution, with a roll call vote by the Clerk.
3.2 Deliberation/Discussion/Debate
   All Council members shall be given the opportunity to speak to any motion,
legislation, or question should he/she so desire. No Council member shall speak
longer than 15 minutes on the same motion, legislation or question without the
permission of the Council President.
   Personal remarks during deliberations or debate are always out of order and
shall be ruled as such by the Council President. Discussion must be directed to
the motion on the floor, not motives and/or personalities. Council members
shall confine their comments and questions to the issues and principles of
proposed legislation.
3.3 Motion to Table
   No motion to "table" may be made until all Council members have had an
opportunity to speak at least once during discussion. A motion to "table" shall
be treated as a motion to temporarily postpone discussion until the next
regular meeting, and may not be used to permanently suspend deliberations on a
proposed ordinance or resolution.
   A motion to table shall require a two-thirds majority to take effect and
shall not be made after a motion to discuss and adopt any emergency
legislation. If tabled, the same Council member who moved to table shall, at
the next regular meeting, move to return the legislation to the business floor
for discussion. Amendments to tabled legislation may be made pursuant to Rule
5.2.
3.4 Motion to Withdraw
   After discussion, any Council member making a motion may request to withdraw
the motion if no other Council member has seconded the motion, or if the
Council member who seconded the motion likewise requests to withdraw the
second, prior to a vote. The Council President shall decide motions to
withdraw.
3.5 Motion to Reconsider or Rescind.
   No Council member shall make a motion to reconsider or rescind during the
same regular meeting after a vote has been taken. Motions to "rescind" and
"reconsider" are restorative motions, and may be used to permit Council to
change or re-evaluate legislation that has been approved or voted down.
   Motions to rescind shall include the original number of the ordinance or
resolution, as the vote shall pertain to the original proposal as submitted to
council.
   Motions to reconsider shall require a new ordinance or resolution number for
any changes to proposed legislation that was not passed or vetoed by the Mayor
without a council override.
3.6 Votes
   All Council members in attendance shall vote "yes," "no," or "abstain" in
response to a roll call vote; in response to a majority voice vote, shall vote
"yes," "no" or remain silent.
   A Council member may not delay voting or "pass" when called upon to cast a
vote.
3.7 Point of Order
   Any Council member may bring a Point of Order to the attention of the
Council President.
   The Council President may ask the Clerk of Council or Director of Law for
clarification of procedural questions at any time. In the event that state law,
the City Charter or these rules do not address a particular procedural matter,
the President, Council Clerk, and/or Director of Law shall consult a recognized
parliamentary procedure guide such as Mason's Manual of Legislative Procedure,
The Standard Code of Parliamentary Procedure, or Robert's Rules of Order. Any
Council member may appeal from a point of order decided by the Council
President by a motion requiring a second and approval by three-quarters
majority vote of Council members present.
Section 4 - Enacting Legislation
4.1 Introduction of Ordinances and Resolutions
   Any member of Council or the City administration (division and department
heads) may introduce an ordinance or resolution, at a regular or special
meeting, which shall contain a concise title and one subject only with two
exceptions to this rule:
   (A)    Appropriation ordinances, which may contain the various subjects,
accounts and amounts for which monies are appropriated; and
   (B)    Compilations of updates to the Codified Ordinances.
   All proposed legislation must be received by the Clerk of Council by 4:00
p.m. on the Tuesday preceding the meeting at which it is to be introduced for a
first reading. The Clerk of Council shall distribute copies of proposed
ordinances and resolutions to each Council Member along with the agenda.
Legislation received after the deadline may be deferred for consideration until
the next regularly-scheduled Council meeting unless authorized by the Council
President or deemed to be an emergency and authorized by the Director of Law.
4.2 Amendments
   A pending ordinance or resolution may be amended at any time after first
reading, prior to its passage by the Council, by a majority vote of the members
of the Council present and voting on the amendment. Such amendment shall not
require additional readings of the ordinance or resolution unless the Director
of Law is absent from a meeting and unable to review the proposed amendment for
conformity to state and federal law.
4.3. Voting
   All Council Members present shall vote upon the Council President's call for
a vote by responding YES or NO, except if the Council Member perceives a
potential conflict of interest, at which time it is permissible to abstain from
voting by responding "ABSTAIN" upon the call. No further elaboration need be
given for abstention other than "conflict of interest," but the Council Member,
in the interest of transparency, may provide a brief explanation for the
minutes. Any Council Member, not being excused, who refuses to vote or abstain,
may be found in contempt of Council and may be censured by a majority vote of
Council.
4.4 Definition of Majority
   For as long as Council consists of seven (7) members, a simple majority
requires the vote of four (4) members, a two-thirds majority requires five (5)
members, and a three-fourths majority requires six (6) members.
Section 5 - General
5.1 Access to Information
   The Clerk shall regularly update and post minutes to the Council-specific
pages of the City of Urbana's website, www.urbanaohio.com. The Clerk serves as
Council's designated public records custodian.
   With the exception of the Council Clerk, Council lacks authority to give
orders to any City employee, and shall inquire directly with the Mayor or
Director of Administration as to administrative affairs of the City (see Urbana
City Charter Section
2.20). For inquiries relating to proposed legislation, however, Council members
may request explanation by a department representative, if one is present at a
Council meeting or work session.
5.2 Notifications/Notice
   Any notice or notification to be given by the Clerk may be given by any
person designated to act on behalf of or under the authority of the Clerk. The
Clerk shall maintain a record of the date and manner, and time, if pertinent
under these Rules, of all actions taken with regard to notices and
notifications under these Rules, and shall retain copies of proofs of
publication of any notifications or notices.
5.3 Conduct of Council Members
   The professional and personal conduct of Council members must be above
reproach and avoid the appearance of impropriety. Council members shall refrain
from abusive conduct or personal attacks upon the character or motives of other
Council members as well as City staff and the general public. Council members
shall prepare for meetings by reviewing agendas, minutes and other information
provided, refrain from interrupting other speakers, practice civility and
decorum in discussion, and avoid arguments with members of the general public
during Council meetings.
5.4 Ethics
   Council Members shall act with honesty and uphold the highest ethical
standards so that public confidence and trust in the integrity, objectivity,
and impartiality of government are conserved and enhanced. Each member of
Council, and the Clerk of Council, shall become familiar and comply with the
most current version of the Ohio Ethics Law (Revised Code Chapter 102) and
related statutes such as Ohio R.C. Chapter 2921. Any Council member who
believes that he or she may have a conflict of interest with a pending issue
should seek the advice of the Director of Law or the Ohio Ethics Commission,
prior to entering into any discussion or voting on that issue.
(Ord. 4601-24. Passed 3-19-24.)
111.03 COUNCIL MEMBER COMPENSATION; TRAINING PROGRAM STIPEND.
   (a)    Effective January 1, 2021, the compensation for any Council Member
shall be set by the Salary Commission pursuant to Section
4.06(k) of the Urbana City Charter. The Director of Finance shall pay each
Council Member in equal monthly installments.
   (b)    Council members may receive an additional stipend for mileage and
reimbursement of costs to attend any training program approved by a majority of
Council, provided that such stipend shall not exceed two hundred dollars
($200.00) annually. Expense reports shall be submitted in a timely fashion to
the Director of Finance.
(Ord. 4601-24. Passed 3-19-24.)
111.04 COUNCIL PRESIDENT COMPENSATION; TRAINING PROGRAM STIPEND.
   (a)   Effective January 1, 2021, the compensation for the Council President
shall be set by the Salary Commission pursuant to Section
4.06(k) of the Urbana City Charter. The Director of Finance shall pay the
President in equal monthly installments.
   (b)   The Council President may receive an additional stipend for mileage
and reimbursement of costs to attend any training program approved by a
majority of Council, provided that such compensation shall not exceed two
hundred fifty dollars ($250.00) annually.
(Ord. 4601-24. Passed 3-19-24.)
111.05 COUNCIL CLERK COMPENSATION.
   (a)   Effective January 1, 2025, the salary scale of the Council Clerk shall
be set at the range of fourteen thousand five hundred dollars to eighteen
thousand five hundred dollars ($14,500.00 to 18,500.00), payable monthly
according to the schedule established by the Director of Finance.
   (b)   Effective January 1, 2025, the Council Clerk shall receive a four
percent (4%) increase from his current pay.
   (c)   From January 1, 2026 forward, increases in the salary of the Council
Clerk shall mirror whatever increases, if any, are authorized for Central
Staff.
(Ord. 4423-25. Passed 4-22-25.)

125.13   ADA Transition Plan.

125.01 MANAGEMENT FUNCTIONS.
   (a)   The Director of Administration shall manage and supervise all
functions within the Department of Administration, except as otherwise provided
by law. Management and supervision shall include establishment of fees, rules
and regulations for the control of all personnel, property, rights of way and
easements of the City except as assigned to the Departments of Finance or Law.
   (b)   The Director shall keep a record of his proceedings, a copy of which,
certified by him, shall be competent evidence in all courts.
   (c)   Except as otherwise provided, the Director shall be signatory to all
contracts entered into by the City. (1984 Code Sec. 31.77)
125.011 ASSISTANT DIRECTOR OF ADMINISTRATION.
   (EDITOR’S NOTE: Former Section
125.011 was repealed by Ordinance 4174, passed January 6, 2004.)
125.02 COMPOSITION.
   The Department of Administration shall be supervised, managed, coordinated
and directed by the Director of Administration. It shall consist of the
following divisions: Public Works, Parks and Recreation, Cemetery, Engineering,
Fire, Police, Community Development and Municipal Airport. It shall be the
mission of the Department to provide Municipal services, within its
jurisdiction, in an efficient and cost effective manner.
(Ord. 3664. Passed 12-18-84.)
125.03 DIVISION OF ENGINEERING.
   The Division of Engineering shall be supervised, managed and directed by the
City Engineer. It shall consist of the Engineering Section and the Building and
Zoning Standards Section. It shall be the mission of the Division to oversee
the engineering requirements of the City, including review of public works
plans and specifications; inspection of City roads and structures as needed;
inspection and repair of sidewalks on City rights of way; supervise public
works construction; issue building and zoning permits; enforce prevailing wage
laws; and identify and correct building, zoning and civil nuisance code
violations.
(Ord. 3664. Passed 12-18-84.)
125.04 DIVISION OF PUBLIC WORKS.
   The Public Works Division shall be supervised, managed, coordinated and
directed by the Superintendent of Public Works. It shall consist of the
following sections: Street, Water, Sanitation, Sewer, Wastewater Treatment and
Public Properties. It shall be the mission of the Division to maintain the
public rights of way within the City, keeping them free of nuisance; to provide
water, clear of harmful agents and of sufficient volume, to properties and fire
hydrants, wherever City owned water mains are installed; to maintain storm and
sanitary sewers, to treat wastewater from the City's sanitary sewer system and
such other sources as are legally authorized; to maintain City lands and
structures not assigned to other divisions; and to collect refuse and trash
from customers of the City's sanitation service and provide for its disposal.
(Ord. 3664. Passed 12-18-84.)
125.05 APPOINTMENT OF SUPERINTENDENT.
   The Director of Administration shall have complete control and supervision
over the employees and the work of the Division of Public Works, subject to
Charter Section
 3.03 and the provisions of Charter
Article V pertaining to civil service. The Director shall appoint the
Superintendent of Public Works who shall be a resident of the City or shall
become a resident within six months of his or her appointment, unless the
residency requirement is waived by the Mayor. The Superintendent shall make
recommendations to the Director for the appointment of supervisors of the
sections within the Division and for the employment of personnel within the
Division.
(1984 Code Sec. 31.86)
125.06 PARKS AND RECREATION DIVISION.
   The Parks and Recreation Division shall be supervised, managed, coordinated
and directed by the Superintendent of Recreation. It shall consist of the
following sections: Parks and Recreation Administration, Parks, Recreation
Programs and Municipal Pool. It shall be the mission of the Division to
operate, maintain and keep free of nuisance, the Municipal Pool, the City's
parklands and such other properties as are assigned to the Division. The
Division shall safely, fairly and impartially operate the Municipal Pool and
all authorized recreation programs of the City. (Ord. 3664. Passed 12-18-84.)
125.07 DIVISION OF MUNICIPAL AIRPORT.
   The Division of Municipal Airport in the Department of Administration is
created and established. (1984 Code Sec. 37.02)
125.08 CEMETERY DIVISION.
   The Cemetery Division shall be managed and directed by the Cemetery
Superintendent. It shall be the mission of the Division to effectively and
efficiently operate and suitably maintain Oakdale Cemetery in the City.
(Ord. 3664. Passed 12-18-84.)
125.09 FIRE DIVISION.
   The Fire Division shall be supervised, managed, coordinated and directed by
the Fire Chief. It shall consist of the Fire Prevention Section and the Fire
Fighting-Ambulance Section. It shall be the mission of the Division to prevent
or extinguish unintentional or unlawful fires, enforce fire codes, provide
ambulance service and protect the public safety and welfare with regard to
fires, chemicals and natural disasters.
(Ord. 3664. Passed 12-18-84.)
125.10 POLICE DIVISION.
   The Police Division shall be supervised, managed, coordinated and directed
by the Police Chief. It shall consist of the following sections: Patrol,
Investigations and Administration. It shall be the mission of the Division to
protect life and property, regulate traffic, investigate criminal offenses and
enforce the laws and ordinances of the State and the City.
(Ord. 3664. Passed 12-18-84.)
125.11 COMMUNITY DEVELOPMENT DIVISION.
   The Community Development Division is supervised, managed and directed by
the Grant Manager/Community Development Officer. The mission of the Community
Development Division shall be to seek, acquire and administer economic and
community development grants (subject to appropriate Council and/or
administration approval); administer and enforce the City's equal opportunity-
affirmative action programs; oversee implementation of revenue sharing
regulations regarding the handicapped; assist in administrative activities of
the Department of Administration and promote economic development activities
within the City.
(Ord. 3664. Passed 12-18-84.)
125.12 BOND REQUIRED OF IMPROVEMENT CONTRACTORS.
   (a)   Any contractor who performs street, utility or Municipal improvement
work of any nature under contract with the City shall furnish a bond with good
and sufficient surety approved by the Director of Administration in an amount
not less than ten percent (10%) of the total contract price. The bond shall be
conditioned to provide indemnity for and to save the City harmless from any
claim presented by any person for any damage resulting from faulty, improper or
incomplete work, repair and construction by any contractor.
   (b)   The bond mentioned in subsection (a) hereof shall remain in force for
one year after the contractor furnishing the bond has notified the City
Engineer that the work or improvement has been completed.
   (c)   The provisions of this section shall be incorporated in contracts made
between the City and improvement contractors.
(1984 Code Sec. 37.01)
125.13 ADA TRANSITION PLAN.
   (EDITOR’S NOTE: Pursuant to Resolution 2561-19, passed August 20, 2019,
Council hereby adopts the Americans with Disabilities Act (ADA) Transition Plan
for the City. A copy is available to view at the City of Urbana Municipal
Building.)

129.01 PROSECUTING ATTORNEY IN MUNICIPAL COURT.
   The Director of Law shall be prosecuting attorney of the Municipal Court.
Provided, however, he may employ an Assistant Director of Law to act as an
assistant prosecuting attorney in Municipal Court. The person designated shall
be subject to the approval of Council. (Ord. 4028. Passed 2-11-97.)
129.02 ASSISTANT DIRECTOR OF LAW; PROSECUTOR IN MUNICIPAL COURT.
   (a)   The salary of the Assistant Director of Law shall be established by
Council and be payable in monthly installments out of the General Fund of the
City. The salary shall be in addition to any allowance of compensation made to
the Assistant Director of Law from funds paid by the County Commissioners
pursuant to Ohio R.C. 1901.34.
   (b)   In the event there is no Assistant Director of Law, the Director of
Law shall also perform the duties of Prosecuting Attorney in the Municipal
Court and in that event, the compensation payable to the Director of Law and
Assistant Director of Law shall be payable to the Director of Law so long as
there is no Assistant Director of Law and the Director of Law shall also
perform the duties of Prosecuting Attorney. Such salary shall be in addition to
any allowance of compensation made by the County Commissioners of the County,
pursuant to the provisions of Ohio R.C. 1901.34, out of County funds.
(Ord. 4028. Passed 2-11-97.)

133.01 INVESTMENT OF TREASURY FUNDS.
   Whenever there are moneys in the Treasury of the City, which will not be
required to be used for a period of six months or more, the moneys may, in lieu
of being deposited in a bank, be invested in the obligations of the City in the
manner prescribed in Sections
133.02 to
133.05.
(1984 Code Sec. 37.03)
 
133.02  PROCEDURE FOR INVESTMENT.
   Whenever any obligations of the City are to be sold and the same are not
taken by the Sinking Fund Commission or when the obligations are otherwise
available for purchase by the City, the Director of Finance shall submit to the
Mayor and to the Director of Law a statement of moneys in the Treasury or in
the process of collection and a schedule showing the probable requirements of
money for the use of the City for the period not less than six months, together
with the recommendation as to whether any moneys in the Treasury should be
invested to the obligations. The Mayor, Director of Law and Director of Finance
may thereupon order the investments of moneys in the Treasury in such
obligations, at not more than par and accrued interest, as they may deem
advisable in the interest of the City. It shall not be necessary to advertise
the bonds before the investment is made. No investment shall be made except in
obligations which have been passed upon and approved as to validity by a
reputable firm of bonded attorneys.
(1984 Code Sec. 37.04)
 
133.03  CONVERSION OF INVESTMENTS INTO CASH.
   Whenever it is necessary to convert any investment, as provided for in
Section
 133.02 into cash, it shall be done by first offering the obligations held by
the City to the Sinking Fund Commission and, if the Commission declines to take
the same or any part thereof, then the remaining obligations shall be sold in
any manner provided by law for the sale of investments by the Sinking Fund;
provided, that no obligations shall be sold for less than par and accrued
interest.
(1984 Code Sec. 37.05)
 
133.04 TREASURY INVESTMENT ACCOUNT.
   The Director of Finance shall maintain an account to be known as the
Treasury Investment Account in which he shall enter all transactions relating
to the investment of Treasury funds as provided in the preceding sections of
this chapter. He shall also maintain a record of all items entered thereon,
showing all bonds or other securities purchased or sold for the account of the
Treasury with the number, maturity date and the interest rate of each. He shall
also keep a record of the number and maturity of interest coupons, and whenever
any securities or interest coupons are due, shall issue his order for the
collection of same in the same manner as other receipts are collected.
(1984 Code Sec. 37.06)
 
133.05 CUSTODY OF SECURITIES; BONDING OF OFFICERS MAKING INVESTMENTS.
   (a)   All securities belonging to the Treasury in any City or to any fund
thereof, other than the Sinking Fund, shall be in the custody of the Director
of Finance and shall be kept by him in a safe deposit box or vault belonging to
a regular City depository. The safe deposit box or vault shall be opened only
in the presence of one or more of the three officers named in Section
133.02 and only upon the warrant or order of the Director directing a deposit
or renewal of a security purchased or sold, or the clipping of interest coupons
for collection. A report of whatever is placed in or removed from the safe
deposit box or vault upon any occasion shall be signed by the Director and by
the witnesses required by this section and shall be returned to the Director
upon the same day.
 
   (b)   Whenever any securities are so held for the City, the officers having
power to make the investments shall be bonded in the amounts as may be provided
by Council in addition to the ordinary official bonds of the officers,
conditioned upon the faithful performance of their duties.
(1984 Code Sec. 37.07)
 
133.06 INTEREST EARNINGS FROM INVESTMENT OF FUNDS.
   All interest earnings received from investment of surplus funds shall be
paid into the City's General Fund, except interest earnings from the investment
of moneys held in trust by the City which are restricted in their use by the
terms of the trust or donation.
(1984 Code Sec. 37.08)
 
133.07 APPROPRIATION OF FUNDS; EXEMPTION FROM BUDGETARY REQUIREMENTS.
   (a)   Funds Deemed to be Appropriated. The following funds shall be deemed
to be appropriated:
      (1)   Money borrowed as provided in Ohio R.C. 133.30;
      (2)   The proceeds of a bond issue duly authorized as provided in Ohio
R.C 5705.41; and
      (3)   Grants or loans of money to the City from the U.S. government or
the State or any department, division, agency, authority or unit thereof as
provided in Ohio R.C. 5705.42
 
   (b)   Funds Exempted From Budgetary Requirements.  Agency funds and certain
types of trust funds shall be exempt from State and local budgetary
requirements as provided in governmental accounting, auditing and financial
reporting standards.
(1984 Code Sec. 37.11)
 
133.08  PERPETUAL AND SUPPLEMENTAL INVESTMENT FUND.
   (a)   A Perpetual Investment Fund is established for the permanent deposit
of the net proceeds of the sale of the Urbana Natural Gas System and the
balance in the Gas Revenue Fund, less outstanding obligations.
 
   (b)   The Director of Finance is directed to transfer the unobligated
balance remaining in the Gas Revenue Fund to the unappropriated balance of the
Perpetual Investment Fund.
 
   (c)   The principal amount of the Perpetual Investment Fund, being the
amount described in subsection (a) hereof, shall be retained for the sole
purpose of investing the amount in the manner allowed by the Charter.
 
   (d)   All the interest or dividend yielded from the Perpetual Investment
Fund shall be allocated to the General Fund or other funds as Council, by
ordinance or resolution, may direct except as provided in subsection (f)
hereof.
 
   (e)   A Supplemental Investment Fund is established for the purpose provided
in subsection (f) hereof.
 
   (f)   The sum of ten percent (10%) of the interest or dividend yielded from
the perpetual investment shall be allocated to the Supplemental Investment Fund
until such time as the fund balance reaches one hundred and fifty thousand
dollars ($150,000) at which time the income yielded from the Perpetual
Investment Fund shall be allocated as provided in subsection (d) hereof. The
income from the Supplemental Investment Fund shall be allocated to that Fund.
If from time to time the balance in the Supplemental Investment Fund shall be
reduced below one hundred and fifty thousand dollars ($150,000), ten percent
(10%) of the income from the Perpetual Investment Fund shall again be allocated
to the Supplemental Investment Fund until such time as the Fund again reaches
one hundred and fifty thousand dollars ($150,000), at which time the income
yielded from the Perpetual Investment Fund shall again be allocated as provided
in subsection (d) hereof. The Supplemental Investment Fund shall be used in the
manner identical to the Perpetual Investment Fund except that Council may, by
ordinance or resolution, appropriate from this Fund for emergency or capital
improvement needs of the City.
(1984 Code Secs. 54.01, 54.02; Ord 3757. Passed 3-8-88.)
 
133.09 PROCESS FOR GIVING NOTICE OF COMPETITIVE BIDDING.
   (a)   With respect to any expenditure by the City which is required to be
competitively bid by state law or by local ordinance, notice of such
competitive bidding shall be published once a week for not less than two
consecutive weeks in a newspaper of general circulation within the City. If the
City posts the notice on the City’s internet site on the world wide web, it may
eliminate the second notice otherwise required to be published in a newspaper
of general circulation within the City, provided that the first notice meets
the following requirements:
      (1)   It is published at least two weeks before the opening of the bids.
      (2)   It includes a statement that the notice is posted on the City’s
internet site on the world wide web.
      (3)   It includes the internet address of the City’s internet site on the
world wide web.
      (4)   It includes instruction describing how the notice may be accessed
on the City’s internet site on the world wide web.
 
   (b)   Notice for competitive bidding shall contain:
      (1)   A general description of the subject of the proposed expenditure.
      (2)   The time and place where plans and specifications or itemized list
of supplies, facilities or equipment and estimated quantities can be obtained
or examined.
      (3)   The time and place bids will be opened.
      (4)   The time and place for filing bids.
         (Ord. 4359. Passed 3-22-11.)
 
 
CHAPTER 137

CROSS REFERENCES
      Civil service classification - see CHTR. Sec.
5.03
      Promotion of Police Chief - see CHTR. Sec.

137.01  ESTABLISHED; MEMBERSHIP.
   The Police Division of the City shall be composed of a Chief of Police, and
such other officers and employees as may be authorized by Council by budget or
otherwise.
(1984 Code Sec. 33.01)
 
137.02  SPECIAL POLICEMEN.
   Council may establish positions for persons as special policemen, who shall
receive such compensation as Council may provide. The Director of
Administration shall be the executive head of this auxiliary unit. The special
policemen shall be subject to the order and direction of the Chief of Police,
and shall conform to and be governed by the provisions of these Codified
Ordinances and other ordinances of the City.
(1984 Code Sec. 33.07)
 
137.03  CONTROL OF JAIL.
   (a)   The City Jail shall be under the control of the Police Chief, who
shall cause the Jail to be kept clean and provided with supplies of bedding and
other necessities for the comfort and safekeeping of persons confined therein.
(1984 Code Sec. 36.21)
 
   (b)   The Police Chief or some member of the Police Division authorized by
him shall receive all persons brought to the City Jail under arrest or legal
process, by the police or other duly authorized officer and shall safely keep
such persons until they are duly released or discharged. During the time the
persons are so confined he shall cause them to be supplied with necessary,
clean, wholesome and properly cooked food.
(1984 Code Sec. 36.23)
 
   (c)   All bills for repairs and supplies for the City Jail and all bills for
food for prisoners shall, after being duly certified to by the keeper of the
City Jail, be presented to the Director of Finance for allowance and payment,
in the customary manner.
(1984 Code Sec. 36.24)
 
   (d)   Any person escaping, attempting to escape or aiding and abetting the
escape or attempted escape from the City Jail shall pay the City the cost of
repair of damage done to City property as a result of the escape or jailbreak
or attempted escape or jailbreak. (1984 Code Sec. 36.25)
 
137.04 LAW ENFORCEMENT TRUST FUND.
   (a)   A special City fund is hereby established which shall be known as the
Law Enforcement Trust Fund (the "Fund" herein) for the benefit of the City
Police Division.
 
   (b)   The Fund is authorized to and shall only receive proceeds distributed
to it under the authority of Ohio R.C. 2933.43.
 
   (c)   The Fund shall be expended only to pay the costs of protracted or
complex investigations or prosecutions, to provide reasonable technical
training or expertise, to provide matching funds to obtain federal grants to
aid law enforcement, and such other law enforcement purposes as Council
determines to be appropriate. Council hereby determines that the purchase of
equipment is an appropriate purpose.
 
   (d)   The Fund shall not be used to meet the operating costs of the City's
Police Division.
 
   (e)   The Director of Finance shall physically control the Fund, but shall
disburse its funds as directed by the Chief of the City Police Division upon
his written requisition which shall specify the purpose for which the funds are
to be expended and the ultimate recipient. All disbursements shall also be made
in compliance with City purchasing regulations as established by the Board of
Control but without the necessity of complying with the provisions of Section
145.01.
(Ord. 3785. Passed 3-14-89.)
 
   (f)   The Fund shall be deemed appropriated. (Ord. 3816. Passed 3-13-90.)
 
137.05 MANDATORY DRUG FINE FUND.
   (a)   A special City fund is hereby established which shall be known as the
Mandatory Drug Fine Fund (the "Fund" herein) for the benefit of the City Police
Division.
 
   (b)   The Fund is authorized to and shall only receive fines otherwise
payable to the City's Police Division under the authority of Ohio R.C. 2925.03.
 
   (c)   The Fund shall be used to subsidize the Police Division's law
enforcement efforts that pertain to drug offenses.
 
   (d)   The Director of Finance shall physically control the Fund, but shall
disburse its funds as directed by the Chief of the City Police Division upon
written requisition which shall specify the purpose for which the funds are to
be expended and the recipient which may be himself. All disbursements shall
also be made in compliance with City purchasing regulations as established by
the Board of Control but without the necessity of complying with the provisions
of Section
145.01.
(Ord. 3786. Passed 3-14-89.)
 
   (e)   The Fund shall be deemed appropriated. (Ord. 3817. Passed 3-13-90.)
 
137.06 EDWARD BYRNE MEMORIAL JUSTICE ASSISTANCE GRANT PROGRAM TRUST FUND.
   (a)   A special City fund is hereby established which shall be known as the
Edward Byrne Memorial Justice Assistance Grant Trust Fund (the “Fund” herein)
for the benefit of the City Police Division.
 
   (b)   The Fund shall be expended only to pay debts or expenses incurred for
eligible activities of either the Edward Byrne Justice Assistance Grant Program
or Recovery JAG Program.
 
   (c)   The Fund shall not be used to meet the operating costs of the City’s
Police Division.
 
   (d)   The Fund may or may not be an interest-bearing account.
 
   (e)   The Director of Finance shall physically control the Fund, but shall
disburse its funds as directed by the Chief of the City Police Division upon
his written requisition which shall specify the purpose for which the funds are
to be expended and the ultimate recipient.
(Ord. 4314. Passed 10-27-09.)
 
CHAPTER 141

141.01 ESTABLISHED; MEMBERSHIP.
   There is established a Fire Division which shall consist of a Chief, and
such other officers and employees as Council shall by budget or otherwise
provide.
(Ord. 4615-25. Passed 4-1-25.)
141.02 CONTRACTS WITH SURROUNDING MUNICIPALITIES FOR EMERGENCY PROTECTION.
   The Mayor and Director of Administration may enter into contracts on behalf
of the City with any city or village in counties contiguous to the County or
any fire district owning motor- driven fire equipment, as they may deem proper,
providing for the exchange of fire-fighting equipment and personnel in the
event of an emergency. The contracts shall provide for the furnishing of fire
protection in the event of the existence of a fire so large that the
municipality within whose limits the fire exists is unable to handle it. The
contracts shall not require either party thereto to leave unprotected or in
jeopardy its own territory and shall provide that the party making an emergency
run shall bear all expenses, loss or damage incurred thereby. The contracts
shall be for a term of three years but may be terminated upon thirty days'
written notice.
(Ord. 4615-25. Passed 4-1-25.)
141.03 INDEMNITY TO EMERGENCY MEDICAL TECHNICIANS.
   The City shall defend and indemnify any member of the Fire Division and Box
13 who is certified EMT-A ADV EMT-A or paramedic from any claim or cause of
action arising out of the performance of the functions of an emergency medical
technician as defined in Ohio R.C. 4731.82 to 4731.99.
(Ord. 4615-25. Passed 4-1-25.)
141.04 FEES FOR AMBULANCE, FIRE, AND RESCUE SERVICES.
   (a)    The City of Urbana Fire Division is hereby authorized to bill
Residents of the City of Urbana and Non-Residents who receive emergency medic,
ambulance transport, and fire rescue services from the Urbana Fire Division.
   (b)    Residents and Non-Residents shall be responsible for the entire bill.
   (c)    Non-Residents shall be sent to the Ohio Attorney General's Office for
collections on non-payment of their bill.
   (d)    The usual, reasonable, and customary fee can be charged for such
services.
   (e)    Usual, reasonable, and customary fees are defined as the fees
established by the Medicare operations and other insurance carriers, as revised
from time to time.
   (f)    The Director of Finance shall supervise the collection of the fees
charged under this section. Billing shall be due within thirty (30) days from
the date rendered.
   (g)    A schedule of fees is available upon request from the City of Urbana.
Ord. 4615-25. Passed 4-1-25.)
CHAPTER 145
Board of Control
145.01   Purchasing powers.
145.02   Bad debt write off.
145.03   To perform duties of Clerk of Board of Control.
 
CROSS REFERENCES
Established - see CHTR. Sec.
4.06(d)
 
145.01 PURCHASING POWERS.
   (a)   The Board of Control shall have full authority to advertise for bids
for purchases or contracts as it deems appropriate.
(Ord. 4051. Passed 12-16-97.)
   (b)   When the Board authorizes the advertising for bids or solicitations of
price quotations of an item estimated to be in excess of fifty thousand dollars
($50,000), it shall within seven calendar days, send notice of such
authorization to the members of Council.
   (c)   Any item of purchase, contract, or personal service contract contained
in the Appropriation Budget in excess of fifty thousand dollars ($50,000) shall
be approved by Council as a motion adopted by a majority of members present and
voting at regular or special meeting of Council. Purchases, contracts, or
personal service contracts not in the Appropriation Budget in excess of seven
thousand five hundred dollars ($7,500) shall be approved by Council as a motion
adopted by a majority of members present and voting at regular or special
meeting of Council.
(Ord. 4410-18. Passed 10-16-18.)
   (d)   Subsections (b) and (c) hereof shall not apply to emergencies or as
are otherwise exempted from bidding requirements of the Ohio Revised Code.
(Ord. 4270. Passed 8-12-08.)
   (e)   In the event of an emergency purchase in excess of seven thousand five
hundred dollars ($7,500), the Board shall notify members of Council of such
purchase as soon as practical.
(Ord. 4410-18. Passed 10-16-18.)
   (f)   The Director of Administration may make purchases and enter into
contracts of two thousand five hundred dollars ($2,500) or less, subject to the
rules governing the Board.
(Ord. 4051. Passed 12-16-97.)
   (g)   The Board of Control may make purchases and enter into contracts in
excess of two thousand five hundred dollars ($2,500) and less than or equal to
fifty thousand dollars ($50,000) when said item is contained in the
Appropriation Budget and subject to the rules governing the Board of Control.
   (h)   The Director of Finance shall be permitted to issue blanket purchase
orders for up to one (1) year in length for annual supplies and services. The
blanket shall not be extended beyond the fiscal year.
(Ord. 4410-18. Passed 10-16-18.)
145.02 BAD DEBT WRITE OFF.
   The Board of Control shall have the authority to direct the Director of
Finance to write off from the books of accounts of the City bad debts owing to
the City which, individually, do not exceed the sum of one thousand dollars
($1,000) and have been outstanding for at least one (1) year.
(Ord. 4410-18. Passed 10-16-18.)
145.03 TO PERFORM DUTIES OF CLERK OF BOARD OF CONTROL.
   The Director of Finance shall perform the duties of the Clerk of the Board
of Control.
(1984 Code Sec. 31.41)
