CROSS REFERENCES
Power to regulate - see Ohio R.C. 715.22, 715.66
Power to establish stands and fix rates - see Ohio R.C. 715.25
Chauffeur's license not required - see Ohio R.C. 4501.01(v)
Operation by minor prohibited - see Ohio R.C. 4507.321
Operation and equipment - see TRAF. CODE
Use of taxicab and bus stands - see TRAF.
351.10
 
 
IN GENERAL
 
767.01 STANDS.
         Taxicabs or other like vehicles licensed under Sections
767.04 to
767.14 shall have a fixed stand, which shall be approved by the Director of
Finance.
(1984 Code Sec. 117.01)
767.02 CRUISING; SOLICITATION OF PASSENGERS.
         Taxicabs and other like vehicles licensed under this chapter shall not
be permitted to cruise seeking employment. No driver of a taxicab or other like
vehicle shall solicit passengers, except at the County Fairgrounds, at other
gatherings and at railroad depots.
(1984 Code Sec. 117.02)
767.03 EXCEPTIONS.
         The provisions of this chapter shall not be construed to apply to any
motor transportation company or person engaged solely in intercity
transportation, to which the State Public Utilities Commission has issued a
license or permit, nor to vehicles engaged solely in the transportation of
children to or from school or school events, nor to any vehicle while it is
used by an employer solely for the transportation of his employees.
(1984 Code Sec. 117.03)
  LICENSES
767.04 PREREQUISITE TO CONVEYING OF PERSONS FOR HIRE.
         No person, other than those exempted in Section
767.03, being the owner, lessee or possessor, or the agent or employee of the
same, of any taxicab or other like vehicle, shall use the same for conveying,
for hire, persons from one part of the City to another part of the City, unless
a license to so use the vehicle is first procured from the Director of Finance
and is in force and effect.
(1984 Code Sec. 117.10)
767.05 APPLICATION FOR TAXICAB LICENSE.
         Application for the taxicab license specified in Section
767.04 shall be made by the owner to the Director of Finance upon blanks
furnished by the Director and shall set forth the name and address of the
applicant, the trade name under which he does business, the design,
specifications, color scheme, letterings, marks and seating capacity of the
vehicle proposed to be licensed, and any other information required by the
Director.
(1984 Code Sec. 117.11)
767.06 DETERMINATION BY DIRECTOR OF FINANCE.
         Upon receiving an application as provided above, the Director of
Finance shall forthwith investigate the applicant for the license concerning
the applicant's general reputation in his residence community, and shall
receive from the Division of Police a report concerning any police record on
the applicant. The Director may refuse to issue an owner's license hereunder,
if the applicant has been convicted of any crime punishable as a felony in the
State.
(1984 Code Sec. 117.12)
767.07 ISSUANCE OF TAXICAB LICENSE.
         If the Director of Finance determines that the license should be
issued, then he shall receive from the taxicab owner prior to delivery of the
license the following:
         (a)    A license fee in the amount of twenty-five dollars ($25.00) per
annum for each taxicab to be licensed; provided, however, that after June 30 in
any year, the fee shall be in the amount of twelve dollars and fifty cents
($12.50) for each taxicab; or at the option of the applicant, a license fee of
one dollar ($1.00) for each day of the term of the license.
         (b)    Evidence of insurance policies as required in Section
767.11 for deposit with the Division of Police.
(1984 Code Sec. 117.13)
767.08 LICENSE SEPARATE AND NONTRANSFERABLE FOR EACH VEHICLE.
         A separate and nontransferable license shall, as referred to in
Section
767.04, be required for each taxicab or other like vehicle licensed under this
chapter.
(1984 Code Sec. 117.14)
767.09 CONTENTS.
         A license, as required under Section
767.04. shall designate the particular vehicle for which the license is issued,
the vehicle when in use pursuant to the license, the time when issued and the
time limits thereof.
(1984 Code Sec. 117.15)
767.10 FEES.
        Before the Director of Finance shall grant any license, as required in
Section
767.04, the applicant therefor shall pay to the Director for the use of the
City, a license fee of one dollar ($1.00) for each day of the term of the
license or, at the option of the applicant, a license fee of twenty-five
dollars ($25.00) per year.
(1984 Code Sec. 117.16)
767.11 INSURANCE.
         No annual license, as required in Section
767.04, and no daily license for any period, except for the period on which any
fair, race or gathering shall be held on the County Fairgrounds , shall be
granted, unless the owner or operator of the vehicle in question has an
insurance policy acceptable to the Director of Finance in conditions, amount
and security to cover all public liability, and all damage to passengers,
arising out of the operation of the vehicle. The insurance policy shall be
maintained in force and effect throughout the entire term of the license or any
renewal or extension thereof.
(1984 Code Sec. 117.17)
767.12 TERM GENERALLY; APPLICATION FOR EXTENSION OF TERM.
         No license, as required in Section
767.04, shall be issued for a term longer than one year and, upon expiration of
the term, the licensee, if he desires to continue operations, shall make an
application to the Director of Finance for an extension of the license.
(1984 Code Sec. 117.18)
767.13 EXTENSION OF TERM BY DIRECTOR OF PUBLIC SERVICE AND SAFETY.
         The Director of Finance, when an application for extension of license
is filed, as provided in Section
767.12, and upon the payment to him for the use of the City of a license fee,
determined as provided in Section
767.10, may extend the term of a license issued under this chapter for a period
no longer than a year.
(1984 Code Sec. 117.19)
767.14 MODIFICATION OF PROVISIONS AND SUBSTITUTION OF EQUIPMENT.
         The Director of Finance, upon application of the holder of a license
issued under this chapter and upon the payment to him for the use of the City
of a fee of one dollar ($1.00), may modify the provisions of the license or
allow the substitution of a vehicle for a vehicle specified in the license.
(1984 Code Sec. 117.20)
767.15 REVOCATION OF TAXICAB LICENSE.
         The Director of Finance shall revoke a taxicab license under the
following circumstances:
        (a)    Whenever the owner of a taxicab for a period of ninety
consecutive days fails to make a reasonable effort to operate any licensed
taxicab, after a hearing before the Director;
         (b)    Whenever the owner of a taxicab permits the operation of the
taxicab by a driver who is not licensed in accordance with the terms of this
chapter;
         (c)    Whenever any owner fails to comply with any reasonable rules
and regulations established by the Director;
         (d)    Whenever the owner is convicted by any court of competent
jurisdiction of a violation of any of the ordinances of the City, or of the
laws of the State, relating to motor vehicles, their operation and equipment,
or is convicted by the court of a violation of the national or State laws or
ordinances of the City, relating to illegal traffic in intoxicating liquor.
(1984 Code Sec. 117.21)
767.16 DRIVER'S LICENSE.
         No person shall drive a taxicab within the City, unless he first
obtains from the Director of Finance a license to drive a taxicab, and unless
the same is in full force and effect.
(1984 Code Sec. 117.22)
767.17 REQUIREMENTS OF TAXICAB DRIVERS.
         No person shall be eligible to receive a taxicab driver's license
unless he shall:
         (a)    Be free of defective vision, defective hearing, epilepsy,
vertigo, heart trouble and any other infirmity, physical or mental, which in
the opinion of the Director of Finance would render him unfit for the safe
operation of a taxicab;
         (b)    Be clean in dress and person and not be addicted to the use of
intoxicating liquor or drugs;
         (c)    Be able to speak, read and write the English language;
         (d)    Possess a current State chauffeur's license which is in full
force and effect;
         (e)    Furnish the certificate of a reputable physician of the City,
stating under oath on blanks furnished by the City that the applicant has been
examined by the physician and is free from each and every physical infirmity
specified in subsection (a) hereof and that no other physical condition
affecting the applicant's ability to drive a taxicab was found to be present in
the examination;
         (f)    Furnish the certificate of a reputable physician, oculist or
optometrist of the City, on blanks furnished by the City setting forth under
oath the applicant's condition as to visual acuity, field of vision and color
vision, together with a statement whether the applicant has any eye condition
which would prevent his driving a taxicab with safety.
(1984 Code Sec. 117.23)
767.18 ISSUANCE OF DRIVER'S LICENSE.
         (a)    Upon receiving the application for a driver's license with the
accompanying material, the Director of Finance shall forthwith refer the same
to the Division of Police for investigation and report. The Director may refuse
to issue the driver's license to any person who has been convicted of a crime
punishable as a felony in the State, or who has been convicted of a misdemeanor
involving moral turpitude.
         (b)    If the Director determines to issue the license, he shall
receive from the applicant a license fee of two dollars ($2.00) per annum,
which fee shall be in addition to any fee required under the laws of the State.
(1984 Code Sec. 117.24)
767.19 RENEWAL OF DRIVER'S LICENSE.
   Application for renewal of a driver's license shall be made not less than
fifteen nor more than forty-five days prior to the date of expiration of the
license, and the renewal shall be subject to all conditions and requirements
specified for the issuance of an original license.
(1984 Code Sec. 117.25)
767.20 REVOCATION OR SUSPENSION OF DRIVER'S LICENSE.
         (a)    The Director of Finance shall have continuing jurisdiction as
to any license granted herein. In the event of violation of any terms of this
or any other ordinance of the City, or any law of the State, or the United
States by a licensed driver, the Director may revoke the license or suspend the
same for a period to be determined by the Director.
         (b)    In the event of misconduct or acts on the part of a licensed
driver which show him to be an unsuitable person to drive a taxicab, or which
would be sufficient to justify the refusal of a license in the case of an
original application, or in the event the Director finds that a licensed driver
is guilty of:
              (1)    Having obtained a license by false statements in his
application;
              (2)    Having been convicted of a felony; or
                (3)    Having been convicted of a misdemeanor involving moral
turpitude; or
                (4)    Having driven a taxicab during a period for which his
license has been suspended;
   Or if the Director finds that a licensed driver has become physically or
mentally incapable of driving a taxicab, then the Director shall forthwith
revoke the license.
         (c)    Whenever a license is revoked or suspended, the Director shall
notify the head of the Division of Police of the revocation or suspension and
the cause therefor.
         (d)    The decision of the Director shall be final in all cases of
revocation or suspension of a driver's license.
(1984 Code Sec. 117.26)
767.21 RULES AND REGULATIONS.
         The Director of Finance is authorized and empowered to establish and
adopt reasonable rules and regulations governing the inspection and operation
of taxicabs, and the issuance, suspension and revocation of taxicabs and
driver's licenses. However, the rules and regulations shall not be inconsistent
with the provisions of this chapter.
(1984 Code Sec. 117.27)
767.22 APPEALS.
         In the case of suspension of an owner's license, revocation of an
owner's license or the granting or refusing of a certificate of public
convenience and necessity, an appeal from the decision of the Director of
Finance to Council may be had by the owner-applicant or by any other owner. The
appeal shall be taken within three days after the decision by filing a notice
thereof with the Clerk of Council Pending the appeal, the decision of the
Director shall remain in force and effect. Council shall determine the
questions of appeal not later than seven days after the filing of the same. The
decision of Council shall be final.
(1984 Code Sec. 117.28)
767.99 PENALTY.
         Whoever violates any provision of this chapter, where another penalty
is not specifically provided, is guilty of a minor misdemeanor for each
offense. Each day during which any violation occurs shall constitute a separate
offense.
CHAPTER 769

769.01 Drilling for oil or gas prohibited.
769.99 Penalty.
 
CROSS REFERENCES
State law provisions - see Ohio R.C. Ch. 1509
 
 
769.01 DRILLING FOR OIL OR GAS PROHIBITED.
         Drilling operations for oil, gas or hydrocarbon within the corporate
limits of the City are hereby prohibited.
(1984 Code Sec. 92.121)
769.99 PENALTY.

769.01 is guilty of a misdemeanor of the fourth degree. Each day's continued
violation shall constitute a separate offense.
CHAPTER 770
Junk Yards
770.01   Definitions.
770.02   Junk yards prohibited.
770.03   Existing junk yards.
770.04   Injunctive relief.
770.05   Enforcement.
 
CROSS REFERENCES
State licensing and required fencing - see Ohio R.C. 4737.05 et seq.
Junk vehicles - see TRAF.
303.09,
303.10
 
 
770.01 DEFINITIONS.
   A "junk yard", as used in this chapter, means an establishment or place of
business used, maintained or operated for the purpose of buying or selling or
storing wrecked, scrapped, ruined or dismantled vehicles or motor vehicle parts
and includes scrap metal processing or storage facilities as defined in Ohio
R.C. 4737.05. It also means an establishment or place of business maintained or
operated for the purpose of buying, selling, storing or salvaging scrap or
discarded material of any kind including trash and waste materials but does not
include a recycling center.
(Ord. 3934. Passed 1-11-94.)
770.02 JUNK YARDS PROHIBITED.
   Junk yards are prohibited within the corporate limits of the City.
(Ord. 3794. Passed 7-18-89.)
770.03 EXISTING JUNK YARDS.
   Any junk yard legally established and operating on the effective date of
this chapter shall not be prohibited by Section
770.02, but shall be adequately screened by a fence or natural objects so as to
completely obscure and enclose the operation. A fence shall be at least eight
feet in height, shall be nontransparent, shall be of uniform material and
neatly constructed and no advertisement shall be permitted thereon. No part of
the junk yard operation shall take place outside its enclosed perimeter and the
exterior shall be landscaped in keeping with the rest of the neighborhood.
(Ord. 3794. Passed 7-18-89.)
770.04 INJUNCTIVE RELIEF.
   The Director of Law, on behalf of the City, may seek injunctive relief
against the operation or continued operation of a junk yard in violation of
Sections
770.02 or
770.03.
(Ord. 3794. Passed 7-18-89.)
770.05 ENFORCEMENT.
   The violation of either Section
770.02 or Section
770.03 is deemed a public nuisance and shall be subject to the abatement
procedures and penalties of Chapter
1339 except for the summary abatement procedures of Section
1339.07 which shall not apply.
(Ord. 3794. Passed 7-18-89.)
CHAPTER 771
Recycling Centers
771.01   Definitions.
771.02   Centers permitted.
771.03   Conditions of operation.
771.04   Injunctive relief.
771.05   Enforcement.
 
 
771.01 DEFINITIONS.
   A "recycling center," as used in this chapter, means an establishment or
place of business used, maintained or operated for the purpose of collecting,
sorting, cleansing, treating and reconstituting waste or other discarded
material for the purpose of recovering and reusing the materials.
(Ord. 3936. Passed 1-11-94.)
771.02 CENTERS PERMITTED.
   Recycling centers are only permitted in areas zoned Heavy Manufacturing
District (M-2).
(Ord. 3936. Passed 1-11-94.)
771.03 CONDITIONS OF OPERATION.
   (a)   The operation of a recycling center shall be conducted solely within
the confines of a building. Provided, nevertheless, materials to be recycled
may be received and stored outside of the building temporarily in completely
enclosed containers designed for the storage of such materials.
   (b)   The operation of a recycling center shall be conducted in such a
manner so as not to produce noxious odors or cause health or fire hazards.
(Ord. 3936. Passed 1-11-94.)
771.04 INJUNCTIVE RELIEF.
   The Director of Law, on behalf of the City, may seek injunctive relief
against the operation or continued operation of a recycling center or
establishment purporting to be a recycling center in violation of this chapter.
(Ord. 3936. Passed 1-11-94.)
771.05 ENFORCEMENT.
   Any violation of this chapter is deemed a public nuisance and shall be
subject to the abatement procedures and penalties of Chapter
1339  except for the summary abatement procedures of Section
1339.07 which shall not apply.
(Ord. 3936. Passed 1-11-94.)
CHAPTER 775
Video Service Provider Fee
775.01   Established.
 
 
775.01 ESTABLISHED.
   (a)   Council hereby establishes a VSP Fee that is calculated by applying a
VSP Fee Percentage of five percent (5%) to the video service provider’s gross
revenues as defined in Section 1332.32(B) of the Video Law. For purposes of
calculating the VSP Fee, the provider’s gross revenues shall include
advertising revenues in accordance with Section 1332.23(B)(2)(g) of the Video
Law.
   (b)   The VSP Fee shall be paid by each video service provider providing
service in the City on a quarterly basis but not sooner than forty-five (45)
days nor later than sixty (60) days after the end of each calendar quarter.
   (c)   The Mayor is authorized and directed to provide any video service
provider with notice of the VSP Fee Percentage and gross revenues definition as
determined by this Council above, which notice shall be given by certified
mail, upon receipt of notice from such video service provider that it will
begin providing video service in the City pursuant to a State-wide video
service authorization.
(Ord. 4260. Passed 1-8-08.)

901.01 CLEANING OF GUTTERS.
   The owner of each lot, part of lot or parcel of land abutting on any gutter
shall clean and remove from any gutter abutting upon the lot so owned, all
material or rubbish not composing a part of the gutter and shall maintain and
keep the gutter free from foreign material and rubbish. All foreign material
and rubbish so removed from the gutter shall be piled in convenient heaps by
the owner and removed by the City Engineer.
(1984 Code Sec. 91.04)
901.02 NOTICE TO CLEAN; CLEANING WHEN RECIPIENT OF NOTICE FAILS TO ACT.
   The Director of Administration shall give written notice to the owner of
lots, parts of lots or parcels of land abutting on any gutter that shall need
cleaning, as required in Section
901.01. If the person so notified does not clean the gutter within ten days
from the service of the notice, the Director shall cause the same to be cleaned
at a reasonable cost, which cost, if not paid within fifteen days after the
cleaning of the gutters, shall be certified to the County Auditor for
collection as taxes are collected.
(1984 Code Sec. 91.05)
901.03 REMOVAL OF ICE OR SNOW FROM SIDEWALKS AND PARKING AREAS.
   (a)   No owner or occupant of any premises within the limits of the City
shall permit or allow snow or ice to remain on any sidewalk or parking area for
more than 24 hours after receiving written notice from the Director of
Administration or the Street Department to remove the snow or ice if it creates
a specific public hazard as documented in the written notice. If snow or ice is
not removed, the Director of Administration or Street Superintendent may
proceed with removal at the expense of the owner or occupant of the premises,
either with City personnel or by contracted services. If such cost is not paid
within 15 days of invoice by the City, the Director of Finance shall certify
the amount owed to the County Auditor in the same manner as a special
assessment for unpaid utilities.
   (b)   No business or property owner may remove snow or ice in a manner that
obstructs vehicular or pedestrian traffic on a sidewalk or street. All ice or
snow cleared from a private property shall be disposed of on private property
in a manner that does not create dangerous conditions for the public.
      (1)   Any plow operator who violates this section by plowing snow and ice
into the street, if observed by a City employee or other competent witness who
documents such action with photographic or video evidence, may be charged with
a violation of Section
311.01 (D) by the Municipal Prosecutor or any law enforcement officer.
      (2)   The City may assess a civil penalty of $100 to a real property
owner or business occupant for a violation that does not involve an eyewitness
observation of the act of plowing/dumping snow into the street or obstructing a
sidewalk. Any City employee who identifies excessive accumulation of snow or
ice on a street or sidewalk abutting a specific parcel shall document that
location to the Street Superintendent. Upon affidavit by the Street
Superintendent which specifies the basis for the allegation of violation, the
Director of Finance shall send notice of liability for a civil penalty by
ordinary mail to the property owner of record listed by the County Auditor, or
the business occupant, within five days of the violation date. If such penalty
is not paid within 30 days of the date of mailing a notice of liability, the
Director of Finance shall add an additional late fee of $50 and assess the
property in the same manner as unpaid utilities. A property owner may appeal
imposition of a civil penalty and/or late fee to the Champaign County Municipal
Court Civil Division within 15 days of the mailing of a notice of liability. An
individual desiring an appeal must first post payment equal to the amount of
the civil penalty and pay any applicable filing fee imposed by the court.
Failure to appeal or pay the penalty within 45 days of the mailing of notice of
liability shall constitute a waiver of the right to contest the notice of
liability. All penalties collected in this manner shall be deposited into the
street fund.
         (Ord. 3948-15. Passed 12-1-15.)
901.04 PAINTING SIGNS ON STREETS.
   No person, except a duly authorized officer or agent of the City shall paint
or mark any sign or lettering or other mark upon any street or sidewalk
pavement or curb in the City.
(1984 Code Sec. 91.09)
901.05 PLACING CLOTHING, GOODS AND MERCHANDISE FROM BUILDING ON SIDEWALK.
   No person shall place any clothing, goods, merchandise, fruit, vegetables or
other articles of trade, or place any table, stand, box or barrel containing
clothing, goods, merchandise, fruit, vegetables or other articles of trade upon
any sidewalk, a greater distance from the building or other line of the lot or
premises than three feet.
(1984 Code Sec. 91.10)
901.06 SNOW EMERGENCY.
   (a)   The Director of Administration may declare weather emergencies
consistent with those declared by the Champaign County Sheriff, or disaster
declarations by the Governor of Ohio and/or the Federal Emergency Management
Agency.
   (b)   The Director of Administration may issue administrative regulations,
not inconsistent with this section, to implement policies pursuant to this
section.
   (c)   The following Snow Emergency classifications will be recognized by the
City of Urbana if declared by the Champaign County Sheriff.
   •   LEVEL 1: Roadways are hazardous with blowing and drifting snow. Roads
may also be icy. Motorists are urged to drive very cautiously.
   •   LEVEL 2: Roadways are hazardous with blowing and drifting snow. Roads
may also be very icy. Only those who feel it is necessary to drive should be
out on the roads. Contact your employer to see if you should report to work.
Motorists should use extreme caution.
   •   LEVEL 3: All roadways are closed to non-emergency personnel. No one
should be driving during these conditions unless it is absolutely necessary to
travel or a personal emergency exists. All employees should contact their
employer to see if they should report to work. Those traveling on the roads may
subject themselves to arrest.
   (d)   Weather emergency declarations and cancellations shall be communicated
to the public through local media outlets, the City website, Local Access
Channel and any other means specified by regulation.
   (e)   Vehicles may be subject to removal for plowing of snow or other
weather related issues if parked on City streets. Vehicles so parked shall be
removed by owners within two hours of any direct route by the Urbana Police
Division or other City employees, or else they may be treated as illegally
parked vehicles subject to tow at the owner’s expense, and/or a parking
citation, under the provisions of Chapter
351  or Section
303.08  of the Urbana Codified Ordinances.
(Ord. 3948-15. Passed 12-1-15.)
901.99 PENALTY.
   Violation of any section of this chapter which does not otherwise specify a
penalty shall be treated as a minor misdemeanor on a first offense. If, within
three years of the date of the violation, a person has been previously
convicted of a violation under this chapter, or a substantially similar
municipal ordinance elsewhere, or any violation of the Ohio Revised Code, the
offense is a fourth-degree misdemeanor.
(Ord. 3948-15. Passed 12-1-15.)

CROSS REFERENCES

905.01 DEFINITIONS.
   As used in this chapter:
   (a)   “Person” means any individual, firm, partnership, association,
corporation, or organization of any kind.
   (b)   “Street” or “highway” means the entire width of every public right of
way when any part thereof is open to the use of the public, including alleys,
as a matter of rights, for purposes of vehicular and pedestrian traffic.
   (c)   "Park" includes all public parks having individual names and under the
ownership and control of the City of Urbana.
   (d)    "Public places" includes all grounds owned by the City of Urbana.
   (e)    "Property line" generally refers to the outer edge of a street or
highway, and may appear as a discontinuation in the terrain: a ditch, a bank, a
hedge, a wall, or similar. Legal boundaries are established by a professional
surveyor who shall provide a legal description of a property as required.
   (f)    "Tree lawn" is that part of a street or highway not covered by a
sidewalk or other paving, lying between the property line and that portion of
the street or highway usually used for vehicular traffic, often this area is
part of the right-of-way.
   (g)    "Property owner” means the person owning such property as shown by
records in the County's Auditor or Recorder Office.
   (h)    "Director" means the Director of Administration or his or her
authorized designee.
   (i)    "Right-of-Way" means any portion of the street, highway, alley, tree
lawn, or sidewalk reserved for the purposes of public maintenance or expansion
of existing service. Typically, the city does not own the fee title to the
property underlying the public right-of-way; the abutting property owners have
that fee title and that title usually extends to the centerline of the right-
of-way.
   (j)    "Street tree" refers to any tree listed on the City's street tree
inventory.
   (k)    "Overhead utility line" refers to wires or cables typically used to
transport electricity or telecommunications overhead between poles.
   (l)   "Underground utility line" refers to wire, cable, piping/conduit,
valves, or meter pits, used to transfer electricity, telecommunications,
natural gas, water, sanitary sewage, storm water, or other productive service
to customers below ground.
   (m)    "OUPS" refers to the Ohio Utilities Protection Service (Ohio 8-1-1),
whose mission is to prevent damage to member facilities and promote public
safety by providing an efficient and effective communication and education
process where digging may conflict with underground utilities.
   (n)    "New tree" refers to a new balled and burlapped, container grown, or
bare root tree with a minimum caliper of 1.0", branched.
   (o)    "Preferred tree list" refers to the list of trees approved by the
Shade Tree Commission, which is reviewed and approved annually, and shall be
used in accordance with this ordinance.
   (p)    "DBH" denotes a tree's Diameter at Breast Height.
   (q)    "Caliper” denotes the commercial sale standard for trees and refers
to trunk diameter.
   (r)    "Aggregate diameter" refers to the commercial standard for measuring
multi-trunk trees.
   (s)    "Large tree" refers to trees with an anticipated mature height in
excess of 45 ft. or more.
   (t)    "Medium tree" refers to trees with an anticipated mature height of
between 30-44 ft.
   (u)    "Line of sight" refers to a straight line which has an unobstructed
view. Refer to City of Urbana Engineering Standard Section 1167.18 of the
Codified Ordinances.
      (Ord. 4159-20. Passed 1-21-20.)
905.02 ESTABLISHMENT OF SHADE TREE COMMISSION.
   (a)   There is hereby established a Shade Tree Commission for the City,
which shall consist of the following members: Director of Administration as ex-
officio, Engineer’s Office on a consulting basis, a representative from Public
Works, six commission members appointed by the Mayor and approved by the City
Council, including one member from each ward and two members who are at large
from the City. In the event that a member cannot be secured to fill a specific
ward seat, then an additional at large member may be appointed in the place of
the ward seat. The six members and the Public Works representative are voting
members and are allowed the following period of appointment: two members can
serve for one year, two members can serve for two years, and three members can
serve for three years. In addition, all meetings of this Commission will be
open to the public.
   (b)   The duties of the Shade Tree Commission shall be to:
      (1)   Study and determine the needs of the City in connection with this
tree planning program; and
      (2)   Recommend to the proper authority the types and kinds of trees to
be planted upon designated streets, parts of streets or parks of the City; and
      (3)   Develop an Administrative Regulation, with which to assist City
officials and citizens in the dissemination of news and information regarding
the selection, planting, and maintenance of trees within the City of private
and public properties and make recommendations from time to time to Council as
to desirable legislation concerning the tree program and related activities of
the City; and
      (4)   Provide regular and special meetings at which the subject of trees
as it relates to the City may be discussed by its members, City officials, and
all other interested in the tree program.
   (c)   Within a reasonable time after the appointment of the Commission and
the approval of its members, upon call of the Mayor such commission shall meet
and organize by the election of a Chairperson and Secretary and the adoption of
rules and procedures including the holding of regular and special meetings as
deemed advisable and necessary to perform the duties of the Commission. (Ord.
4159-20. Passed 1-21-20.)
905.03  TREE PLANTINGS; DIRECTION, REGULATION, AND CONTROL OF TREES.
   The guiding principle for the City's Tree Ordinance shall be in keeping with
the arboricultural industry's "best practice" of RIGHT TREE, RIGHT PLACE which
emphasizes the selection of the proper tree for the proper location and site
conditions.
   (a)    The Director shall direct, regulate, and control the planting,
maintenance, removal, fertilization, pruning, and bracing of trees on the
streets and other public places in the City; and shall cause the provisions of
this chapter to be enforced. In his or her absence, the duties shall be the
responsibility of a qualified alternate designated by the Director.
   (b)    The Director shall have the authority to affix reasonable conditions
to the granting of permits in accordance with the provisions of this chapter
and to ensure safety and preserve the aesthetics of public places. Exceptions
may be made upon written recommendations from the Urbana Shade Tree Commission
to the Director.
      (1)    All street trees shall only be those tree species listed on the
preferred tree list, and such trees shall only be planted within the tree lawn,
with written permission from the property owner.
      (2)    The City reserves the right to remove street trees within the
right-of-way when operational, construction, or other business needs of the
City dictate.
      (3)    Large and medium trees shall be preferable and considered for
planting as street trees in the tree lawn with the appropriate tree lawn width
and when listed on the Preferred Tree List.
      (4)    The following minimum widths of tree lawns should be followed for
tree planting: eight (8) feet for large trees, and six (6) feet for medium
trees.
      (5)    All planting of trees within the public right-of-way shall be
prohibited without an approved right-of-way permit through the Engineering
Office.
      (6)    The minimum spacing of new street trees shall follow the following
regulations: sixty (60) feet between large trees, forty (40) feet between
medium trees.
      (7)    All new street trees shall be planted a minimum of fifteen (15)
feet from all signs, driveways, and fire hydrants, and a minimum of forty (40)
feet from overhead power/electric lines (for medium trees) and sixty (60) feet
(for large trees).
      (8)    All new street trees shall be planted a minimum of ten (10) feet
from all underground utilities. Planting shall be permissible in the tree lawn
parallel to natural gas mains if the ten (10) feet clearance is maintained.
      (9)    All new street trees shall be planted a minimum of thirty (30)
feet from all intersections.
      (10)    Trees shall not be planted under overhead utility lines.
   (c)    The Director shall have the authority to formulate a Master Street
Tree Plan after a public hearing and after receiving the recommendation of the
Shade Tree Commission. The Master Street Tree Plan shall specify the species of
trees to be planted on the streets and in public places within the City. From
and after the adoption and approval of such Plan by the Commission, or any
amendment thereof, all plantings shall conform thereto. Such factors in
determining the species of the trees for the various locations, and such Plan
may be amended by the Director, with the approval of the Commission, as
circumstances require. The Commission has the authority to develop a Preferred
Tree List of acceptable and unacceptable trees that shall be reviewed, revised,
and approved each calendar year.
      The Commission shall have the authority to develop and recommend other
policies and procedures as long as these policies and procedures are in full
accordance with this chapter. (Ord. 4159-20. Passed 1-21-20.)
905.04 PERMITS REQUIRED.
   (a)    No person shall plant or remove any tree on any tree lawn, right-of-
way, or within a public place, without first filing an application and
procuring a Tree Work Permit from the City
Engineer's Office . The person being issued the permit shall abide by all
regulations, conditions, and specifications prescribed on the issued permit.
   (b)    The application for the permit shall contain information as to the
location, type, grade and species, cultivar, method of planting, and any other
such information as the City Engineer's Office finds reasonably necessary.
   (c)    Applications for permits, accompanied by the permit fee shall be
filed at the office of the City Engineer not less than forty-eight hours in
advance of the time the work is to be done.
   (d)    The City Engineer's Office shall issue the Tree Work Permit if, in
their judgment, the proposed work is desirable and is in conformity with the
City's tree ordinance, the City's
Master Street Tree Plan and the proposed method and workmanship are of
satisfactory nature. The permit shall contain a definite date of expiration;
the work shall be completed in the time allowed by the permit and in accordance
with the provisions of this chapter, and as the City Engineer's Office may
additionally prescribe. Any permit shall be void if its terms or the provisions
of this chapter are violated.
   (e)    All permit holders shall advise the City Engineer's Office within
five days of the completion of the work under the permit in order that the City
Engineer's Office might inspect the work for compliance.
   (f)    Whenever any tree is planted or set out in conflict with the
provisions of this chapter, the Engineer's Office and/or Director may remove or
cause the removal of the same and the cost thereof shall be assessed in
accordance with the provisions of the Ohio Revised Code.
   (g)    When it is necessary to remove trees from a tree lawn in connection
with the repair,
replacement or construction of a sidewalk, street or other public improvement
under a City program, the City shall replant or replace such trees when
feasible, and with written approval of the property owner.
   (h)    Utility companies or their contractors shall provide written evidence
to the Engineer's Office of their supervisory personnel's knowledge and
expertise in order to ensure strict adherence to established guidelines for
utility pruning (as recommended by the American National Standards Institute
(ANSI), for line clearance work. These guidelines shall cover the following
areas:
      (1)    Tree trimming/pruning,
      (2)    Tree removal,
      (3)    Brushing,
      (4)    Right-of-way, clearance for new transmission line, and
      (5)    Chemical brush control and appropriate precautions.
   The contractor being hired by the utility company shall provide
documentation that an ISA Certified Arborist will be supervising any crews
undertaking line clearance work within the City. Prior to scheduled line
clearance of trees in the City, the utility company or its contractor shall
meet the conditions above and obtain the Tree Work Permit and notify the City
Engineer's Office of the proposed time schedule.
   (i)   All departments of the City shall be exempt from these permit
provisions, however, City staff shall notify the City Engineer's Office and/or
Director before any tree related or impacted work commences.
   (j)   Any person affected by any rule or regulation within this chapter and
the enforcement thereof, shall have the right of appeal by submitting a written
appeal within ten (10) days of receipt of any notice, order, or direction of
the Director or his or her designee. In response to an appeal, a hearing before
the Shade Tree Commission shall be granted. The Commission shall recommend to
reverse or affirm, in whole or in part, or modify such rule, regulation,
notice, order, or direction pursuant to this chapter. (Ord. 4159-20. Passed 1-
21-20.)
905.05  PRUNING AND REMOVAL OF OBSTRUCTIONS REQUIRED.
   (a)    At their own expense, a person owning or occupying real property
bordering on a street or right of way upon which property there are trees,
shall prune, trim, remove or cause to be pruned, trimmed or removed, any tree,
tree branches, limbs, bushes, shrubs or other type of vegetation, whether
living or dead, in front of, or on their respective lots or parcels of land, so
as to permit an unobstructed view of traffic or traffic signs, street or alley
intersections, and an unobstructed passage for vehicular or pedestrian traffic
on all streets, sidewalks, alleys and public grounds, as determined by the City
Engineer's Office and Shade Tree Commission.
   The minimum free overhead clearance of an overhanging portion of a tree
shall be nine (9) feet over sidewalks and thirteen and one-half (13-1/2) feet
over all streets.
   (b)    No person shall maintain or permit to remain on his property a tree
whose roots obstruct or impede the flow of liquid through any public sewer,
drain, or water main in the City.
The Director shall refer the owners or agents of any land or parcel of land who
fail to comply with the requirements of subsection (a) and (b) hereof to the
City's Zoning Officer, and the noncompliance shall be addressed in accordance
with Chapter 1339 - Nuisances, of the City
of Urbana's Codified Ordinances. (Ord. 4159-20. Passed 1-21-20.)
905.06 ABUSE OR MUTILATION OF TREES.
   (a)    Unless specifically authorized by the Director, no person shall
intentionally damage, cut, carve, transplant, or remove any public tree; or
attach any rope, wire, nail, advertising poster, or order contrivance to any
public tree; or allow any gaseous, liquid, or solid substance which is harmful
to such trees to come in contact with them, or set fire or permit any fire to
burn when such a fire or heat thereof will injure any portion of any tree.
   (b)    No person shall excavate any ditch, tunnel, or trench, or lay any
drive within ten (10) feet of a public tree without first obtaining a written
permit therefore from the City Engineer.
   (c)    A person excavating or constructing a building or structure near a
public tree shall construct a substantial fence, frame, or box to guard the
drip line of such a tree and shall keep all building materials, dirt, or other
debris outside such barrier.
   
   (d)    No person shall deposit, place, store, or maintain upon any public
place or right of way in the City, any stone, brick, sand, concrete, or other
material which may impede the free passage of water, air, and fertilizer to the
roots of a tree growing therein except by the written
permission of the City Engineer.
   (e)    Flat topping of any public trees is hereby prohibited with the
exception of trees severely damaged by storms or other causes, or certain trees
under utility wires or other obstructions where standard pruning practices are
impractical may be exempted from this section at the determination of the
Director or Tree Commission. Where existing street trees within the tree lawn
are located under overhead utility lines and line clearance work is required,
the utility company or its contractor shall consider complete removal of the
tree instead of repetitive line clearance work. (Ord. 4159-20. Passed 1-21-20.)
905.07 SHADE TREE MEMORIAL FUND.
   There is hereby established a special fund to be designated as the Shade
Tree Memorial Fund which Fund shall be utilized for the receipt of gifts and
donations for the purpose of purchasing and planting of shade trees under the
provisions of this chapter.
(Ord. 4159-20. Passed 1-21-20.)
905.99 PENALTY.
   Whoever violates or fails to comply with any of the provisions of this
chapter is guilty of a minor misdemeanor. A separate offense shall be deemed
committed each day during on or which a violation occurs or continues.
(Ord. 4159-20. Passed 1-21-20.)

CROSS REFERENCES

521.03
 
 
909.01 UNAUTHORIZED TEARING UP OR REMOVING OF SIDEWALKS.
         No unauthorized person shall tear up, loosen, make any opening in,
remove or in any manner injure or deface any portion of any sidewalk in the
City.
(1984 Code Sec. 91.30)
909.02 NOTICE OF INTENTION TO BUILD SIDEWALK.
         Any person desiring to build, rebuild, repair or disturb any sidewalk
in the City shall first notify in writing the City Engineer of the intention to
do so, stating in the notice the location and character of the proposed work
and the time when the same is proposed to be done. However, the work shall
conform to the specifications on file in the office of the City Engineer.
(1984 Code Sec. 91.31)
909.03 TEARING UP, OR EXCAVATING STREETS GENERALLY.
         Except as provided in this section, no person, other than a duly
authorized person in Sections
909.05 and
909.06 shall tear up, loosen, make any opening or excavation in, remove or in
any manner injure or deface any portion of any public roadway or area or any
pavement thereof, in the City. Whenever any person desires to have any opening
made, he shall file with the City Engineer a written application specifying the
opening desired to have made, its purpose and extent, and the time when it is
desired or necessary. The provisions of this section shall not apply to the
planting of shade trees or the removal thereof, outside of the curb lines or
the lines established for curb lines.
(1984 Code Sec. 91.32)
909.04 PAYMENT OF COST OF REPAIRS OUTSIDE OF CURB LINES WHEN UTILITY LINE
BREAKS.
         In the event of the breakage or clogging of a sewer or water line, all
the cost and expense, outside of the curb lines, that is, upon the property
owner's side of the curb line, of excavation, repair, refilling and restoring
the sidewalk to its former condition shall be borne by the owner of the lot or
land on which the sewer or water line is situated or on which the sidewalk
bounds and abuts.
(1984 Code Sec. 91.33)
909.05 EXCAVATION AND REPAIR BETWEEN CURB LINES WHEN SEWER LINE BREAKS.
         In the event of breakage or clogging of a sewer line, all the work of
excavating, repairing, refilling and restoration of pavement or roadway between
the curb lines shall be done at the expense of the City, by City labor under
the direction of the Director of Administration.
(1984 Code Sec. 91.34)
909.06 EXCAVATION AND REPAIR BETWEEN CURB LINES WHEN WATER LINE BREAKS.
         In the event of breakage or clogging of a water line, all the work of
excavating, repairing, refilling and restoration of pavement or roadway,
between the curb lines, shall be done at the expense of the Department of
Administration of the City. The actual work of refilling and restoration shall
be done by City labor under the direction of the Director of Administration,
and the actual work of excavating and repair shall be done by the Division of
Public Works, but only on permit granted by the Director.
(1984 Code Sec. 91.35)
909.07 LIGHTS, FENCES AND GUARDS IN EVENT OF EXCAVATION REQUIRED.
          In the event of any excavating, repairing or disturbance of the
surface or substratum within the boundaries of any street, proper and adequate
warning lights, fences, guards and signs shall be placed and the Director of
Administration shall have authority to determine whether the same are proper
and adequate, and if they are not, to direct what proper protection shall be
placed.
(1984 Code Sec. 91.37)
909.08 REMOVAL OF LIGHTS OR BARRIERS.
         No person shall remove, disturb or tamper with any of the protection
placed in accordance with the provisions of Section
909.07, except under the express direction of the Director of Administration or
the City Engineer.
(1984 Code Sec. 91.38)
909.09 WALKING UPON STREET OR SIDEWALK UNDER CONSTRUCTION.
         No person shall walk upon any street or sidewalk under construction,
replacement or repair, until the party constructing the same shall have
entirely completed the same and removed the guard and warnings.
(1984 Code Sec. 91.39)
909.10 INJURING STREET UNDER CONSTRUCTION.
         No person shall do any act that may injure, impair or damage any
street or sidewalk under construction, replacement or repair.
(1984 Code Sec. 91.40)
909.99 PENALTY.
         Whoever violates any provision of this chapter is guilty of a
misdemeanor of the first degree.
CHAPTER 913
Construction and Repair of Sidewalks and Curbs
913.01   Construction of sidewalk, curb and gutter by owner of lot abutting
street.
913.02   Requirement to install sidewalks.
913.03   Repair of sidewalk by owner of lot.
913.04   Material for sidewalks.
913.05   Material for curbstone and gutter.
913.06   Grade and slope.
913.07   Width of sidewalks.
913.08   Construction specifications and standards.
913.09   Design specifications and standards.
913.10   Enforcement.
913.11   Appeals.
 
CROSS REFERENCES
Sidewalks and gutters - see Ohio R.C. 729.01 et seq.
Construction or repair at owner's expense - see Ohio R.C. 729.01 et seq.
Notice to construct or repair sidewalks - see Ohio R.C. 729.03 et seq.
Maintenance of sidewalks - see GEN. OFF.
521.06
 
 
913.01 CONSTRUCTION OF SIDEWALK, CURB AND GUTTER BY OWNER OF LOT ABUTTING
STREET.
   The owner of each lot, part of lot or parcel of land fronting or abutting on
any of the public streets or any of the public grounds of the City shall
construct, or cause to be constructed, along the whole of the front of his lot,
part of lot or parcel of land, under the requirements of Section
913.02, a good and sufficient sidewalk, curbstone and gutter, laid and set to
conform to the provisions of this chapter.
(Ord. 4357. Passed 2-8-11.)
913.02 REQUIREMENT TO INSTALL SIDEWALKS.
   Sidewalks shall be required to be installed by the property owner or
subdivision developer in the following cases:
   (a)   Major subdivisions as covered in the provisions of Section
1161.32.
   (b)   Any new construction, including minor subdivisions, or substantial
expansion, as defined in Section
1110.01, to an existing structure within a residential or business district of
the City.
   (c)   Any new construction or substantial expansion to an existing structure
within a zoning overlay district, such as the City Center Heritage Overlay
District and the Corridor Overlay District, according to the provisions of the
district.
   Construction of these sidewalks shall be governed by the City or Urbana
Design Criteria, Construction Standards and Drawings, and the provisions of the
applicable overlay district. Where multiple design criteria or construction
standards apply, the most restrictive shall govern as determined by the City
Engineer. The owner or developer who constructs a sidewalk is responsible for
curb ramps at intersections. Owners or developers shall be required to install
sidewalks on individual properties prior to the issuance of a certificate of
occupancy. If the sidewalks are not installed, the City will perform the
installation and assess the owner for all costs incurred plus ten percent (10%)
according to the provisions of Section 913.20.
(Ord. 4357. Passed 2-8-11.)
 
913.03 REPAIR OF SIDEWALK BY OWNER OF LOT.
   The owner of each lot, part of lot or parcel of land in front of or against
which a sidewalk and curb and gutter has been, or may hereafter be constructed,
shall keep the same in good order and repair in accordance with the provisions
of this chapter.
(Ord. 3868. Passed 5-14-91.)
913.04 MATERIAL FOR SIDEWALKS.
   A sidewalk constructed or repaired as required by this chapter, shall be
constructed of or repaired with Portland Cement concrete or other material that
the City Engineer shall, in each case, approve in writing.
(Ord. 3868. Passed 5-14-91.)
913.05 MATERIAL FOR CURBSTONE AND GUTTER.
   Curbstones and gutters constructed or repaired as required by this chapter,
shall be constructed of or repaired with Portland Cement concrete or other
material that the City Engineer shall in each case, approve in writing.
(Ord. 3868. Passed 5-14-91.)
913.06 GRADE AND SLOPE.
   All sidewalks shall conform to the adopted grade of the street and slope or
incline toward the gutter, or outer side, in accordance with the specifications
established by the City Engineer.
(Ord. 4357. Passed 2-8-11.)
913.07 WIDTH OF SIDEWALKS.
   All constructed or repaired sidewalks shall be a minimum width of four feet.
However, the width of replaced sidewalks or portions thereof shall conform to
their existing widths if greater than the required minimum width.
(Ord. 3868. Passed 5-14-91.)
913.08 CONSTRUCTION SPECIFICATIONS AND STANDARDS.
        Except and otherwise provided in this chapter, the specifications and
standards for the design and materials to be used in the construction or repair
of sidewalks, curbs and gutters as well as the requirements as to methods of
construction hereafter to be employed in the construction or repair of
sidewalks, curbs and gutters shall be established by the City Engineer.
(Ord. 3868. Passed 5-14-91.)
913.09 DESIGN SPECIFICATIONS AND STANDARDS.
         Council may, by resolution, adopt special design specifications for
the construction, repair or replacement of sidewalks, curbs and gutters under
this chapter. Such special design specifications may be adopted from time to
time and for such area within the City as Council shall reasonably determine.
Council shall base its determination upon the comparative cost and the public
purpose to be served in achieving a safe, harmonious and integrated plan for
sidewalk construction, repair and development for the area involved. Council
also reserves the right to grant variances from any such special design
specifications. As used herein, “variance” shall have the same meaning as set
forth in Section
1102.01. Variances may only be granted upon the written application of an
affected party filed with the Clerk of Council. Such applications shall be in
the form prescribed by Council and Council shall grant or deny applications
within thirty days from the date of filing. Failure of Council to grant or deny
such applications within the time specified shall be considered a denial of
such applications. The City Engineer shall maintain records of the applications
filed and the disposition made of each, all of which shall be certified to him
by the Clerk of Council. (Ord. 4357. Passed 2-8-11.)
913.10 ENFORCEMENT.
         (a)    If sidewalks, curbs or gutters are not installed per Section
913.02 and the property continues to fail to comply after thirty days prior to
written notice, the owner shall be fined twenty-five dollars ($25.00) per day
for so long as the violation remains unremedied. The notice shall be given by
the City Engineer and shall be served on the property owner by ordinary first
class mail unless the owner does not occupy the premises, in which event the
notice shall be sent ordinary first class mail to his or her last known address
and also shall be sent to the occupant of the property, if there is one. After
thirty days noncompliance from the date of the letter, the Director of
Administration may have the construction done at the expense of the owner. All
the expense shall be assessed by the foot front on the respective properties
bounding and abutting thereon. The assessment shall be collected in the same
manner, with penalty of ten percent (10%), as in the case of improvement under
the laws of the State.
 
         (b)    Any property owner who, after thirty days prior written notice,
continues to fail to comply with Section
 913.03 shall be fined twenty-five dollars ($25.00) per day for so long as the
violation remains unremedied. The notice shall be given by the City Engineer
and shall be served on the property owner by ordinary first class mail unless
the owner does not occupy the premises in which event the notice shall be sent
ordinary first class mail to his or her last known address and also shall be
sent to the occupant of the property, if there is one. The notice shall advise
the recipient of his right of appeal under Section 913.21. Such fines may be
collected by civil suit if not otherwise paid. The City Engineer, in the
exercise of his reasonable discretion, may extend the time for compliance and
abate the daily fine.
   (c)   The foregoing remedies shall not be deemed exclusive and shall be in
addition to the procedures provided for in ORC Chapters 727 and 729 otherwise
by law.
(Ord. 4357. Passed 2-8-11.)
913.11 APPEALS.
         (a)    Any property owner who received a written notice from the City
Engineer pursuant to Section 913.20(b) may file an appeal with the Building and
Zoning Appeals Board requesting a review of the City Engineer’s determination
that his sidewalk or curb and gutter, or both, is in need of repair or the
reasonableness of his specifications and standards.
   (b)   The appeal shall be taken by filing a written notice of appeal with
the City Engineer specifying the grounds of the appeal. The appeal shall be
filed within ten days after the receipt of the written notice from the
Engineer. The City Engineer shall immediately transmit to the Board his entire
written record of the matter.
   (c)   Upon receipt of the notice of appeal, the Board shall set a time and
date for a hearing and shall notify the appellant and the City Engineer of the
hearing. The appellant and the City Engineer shall have the right to appear, be
heard, present evidence and be represented by counsel.
   (d)   The Board shall review the decision of the City Engineer complained of
only for the purpose of determining whether the Engineer has acted arbitrarily,
capriciously, unreasonable or illegally.
   (e)   The Board shall act upon the appeal no later than its second regularly
scheduled meeting following the hearing. Its decision shall be in writing and
shall be sent to the appellant and the City Engineer.
   (f)   An appeal shall automatically stay all enforcement proceedings until
the appeal is decided. (Ord. 4357. Passed 2-8-11.)
CHAPTER 917
Numbering of Buildings
917.01     Duty of owner or occupant of building to affix.
917.02     Distance for which number allowed; numbering of rooms in business
portion of City.
917.03     Plan of numbering.
917.04     Designation of numbers.
917.05     Altering numbers.
917.99     Penalty.
 
CROSS REFERENCES
Power to regulate - see Ohio R.C. 715.26
 
 
917.01 DUTY OF OWNER OR OCCUPANT OF BUILDING TO AFFIX.
         (a)    Every owner or occupant of any building, house, place of
business or place of residence shall, place or permanently fix in a color
contrasting with its background on or in front of the building, house, place of
business or place of residence the proper number thereof and maintain the
number in a legible manner. The figures of the numbers so affixed shall not be
less than four inches in height, or not less than three inches in height if
electrically illuminated from the rear, facing the designated street and be
plain and legible from such street. For purposes of this subsection, the
designated street shall be the street from which the address is derived.
Notwithstanding the previous provisions, a structure numbered with numerals of
one and one-half inches or larger, on or before May 1, 1991, shall be in
compliance with this subsection until such numerals are replaced or shall
become illegible or otherwise not functional.
         (b)    For new construction, the proper number shall be displayed on
the property or affixed to the structure as provided in subsection (a) hereof
within ten days after construction is begun. No certificate of occupancy shall
be issued until the provisions of subsection (a) hereof
are met.
(Ord. 3858. Passed 3-12-91.)
917.02 DISTANCE FOR WHICH NUMBER ALLOWED; NUMBERING OF ROOMS IN BUSINESS
PORTION OF CITY.
         Under Sections
917.01 to
917.05, a number shall be allowed for every twenty feet front. Houses shall be
numbered according to the number of the space in which they fall. In the
business portion of the City, as provided in the Zoning Ordinance, where
permanent rooms are now established they shall be numbered in order as they
come, allowing a full number for each stairway leading up to offices or
workrooms, provided that the block is built up solid, one room joining onto
another.
(1984 Code Sec. 91.71)
917.03 PLAN OF NUMBERING.
         (a)    The plan of numbering Monument Square shall be to number to the
right, commencing with No. 1 at the Citizen's National Bank corner.
                (1)    Miami Street and Scioto Street shall be numbered from
Monument Square, east and west, the even numbers on the north and odd numbers
on the south side of the streets.
              (2)    North Main Street and South Main Street shall begin at
Monument Square and shall be numbered north and south, with even numbers on the
west and odd numbers on the east side of the streets.
              (3)    All streets running east and west shall be numbered east
from North Main Street and South Main Street eastwardly and west from North
Main Street and South Main Street westwardly, with odd numbers on the south and
even numbers on the north side of the streets.
              (4)    All streets running north and south shall be numbered
north from Miami Street and Scioto Street northwardly and south from Miami
Street and Scioto Street southwardly, with even numbers on the west and odd
numbers on the east side of the streets.
                (5)    All streets north of Miami Street and Scioto Street and
running north and south, but not intersecting either, shall be numbered
northwardly from the south termini of the streets, with even numbers on the
west and odd numbers on the east side of the streets.
              (6)    All streets south of Miami Street and Scioto Street and
running north and south, but not intersecting either, shall be numbered
southwardly from the north termini of the streets, with even numbers on the
west and odd numbers on the east side of the streets.
              (7)    All streets east of North Main Street and South Main
Street and running east and west, but not intersecting either, shall be
numbered eastwardly from the western termini of the streets, with odd numbers
on the south and even numbers on the north side of the streets.
              (8)    All streets west of North Main Street and South Main
Street and running east and west, but not intersecting either, shall be
numbered westwardly from the eastern termini of the streets, with odd numbers
on the south and even numbers on the north side of the streets.
              (9)    All streets shall be numbered to begin with number 100;
the second block with 200; the third block with 300, and so on; each block to
count for 100.
                (1984 Code Sec. 91.72)
917.04 DESIGNATION OF NUMBERS.
         The City Engineer shall furnish a certificate to all persons
requesting the certificates, together with any information that the person may
desire as to the proper number to be placed on his house, building, place of
business or place of residence. (1984 Code Sec. 91.74)
917.05 ALTERING NUMBERS.
         No person shall take down, alter or deface any number assigned and put
up as provided in Sections
917.01 to
917.05 or retain an improper number or substitute any number on their building,
house, place of business or place of residence other than the number assigned
pursuant to Sections
917.01 to
917.05. (1984 Code Sec. 91.75)
917.99 PENALTY.
         Whoever violates any provision of this chapter is guilty of a
misdemeanor of the first degree.

909
 
 
EXTENSION OF LINES
 
927.01 PETITIONS.
   (a)   All extensions of water and sanitary sewers to an individual house or
upon any duly dedicated and accepted street in the City shall be petitioned for
by the owners of the lots bounding and abutting on the extensions. The
petitions shall bear the approval of seventy-five percent (75%) of the
landowners or eighty percent (80%) of the owners of the foot frontage of the
lands bounding and abutting upon the extensions with the following exceptions
for sanitary sewers:
      (1)   New subdivisions where Subdivision Regulations shall govern.
      (2)   Any dedicated right of way where the property on each side of the
proposed extensions has been previously assessed for a sewer.
      (3)   Dedicated streets where it is impossible for the petitioner to
obtain the proper percentage of signatures.
   (b)   The petitioners shall further bear the agreement of the landowners to
assume the costs of the extension as set forth in Section
927.02.
(1984 Code Sec. 50.01)
927.02 COST; SIZE OF MAINS; PAYMENT OF LEAD-INS.
   (a)   The cost of the extension of any water main on any duly dedicated and
accepted street in the City shall be borne on the basis of sixty percent (60%)
of the cost paid by the owners of the land bounding and abutting on the
extension and forty percent (40%) paid by the City. Such percentages apply up
to and including six inch mains and, if the City deems it necessary to have a
larger size main, the additional cost of the main shall be borne by the City.
The size of the main shall be determined by the City Engineer.
   (b)   The cost of the extension of any gas main on any duly dedicated and
accepted street in the City shall be borne on the basis of sixty percent (60%)
of the cost paid by the owners of the land bounding and abutting on the
extension and forty percent (40%) paid by the City. The percentages apply up to
and including six inch mains and, if the City deems it necessary to have a
larger size main, the additional cost of the main shall be borne by the City.
The size of the main shall be determined by the City Engineer.
   (c)   The owners of the foot frontage shall pay for all lead-ins from the
main to the property line at their sole expense on all of the above extensions
of water, gas or sanitary sewer.
   (d)   The total cost of all local service sewers and laterals shall be
assessed to the property owners when installed after being petitioned by
seventy-five percent (75%) of the property owners or eighty percent (80%) of
the frontage benefitted by the sewer. The City shall bear the cost of providing
a suitable outlet for the proposed extension within the right-of-way limits of
the street containing the outlet sewer in all cases. Trunk sewers shall be
installed at the expense of the City.
   (e)   On any dedicated right of way where the exception in
927.01(a)(2) applies, the petitioners shall bear sixty percent (60%) of the
cost of the sewer and the City forty percent (40%) of the cost for the frontage
which cannot be assessed if so approved by Council.
   (f)   On any dedicated right of way where it is considered necessary for the
health, progress and welfare of the City by the Superintendent of Public Works
and Council to install a sanitary sewer, Council may order the construction of
a local service sewer and assess the total cost of the sewer to all the owners
of all the lots benefitted by an improvement without the percentage of
signatures of owners as specified by the rule of petition in Section
927.01. If this method is not considered economically feasible and fifty
percent (50%) of the property owners on the improvement have signed a petition,
Council may order the construction on a basis of sixty percent (60%) of the
total cost of the sewer main assessed to the petitioners and forty percent
(40%) to the City. In this case, a record of parcels not assessed shall be
given to the Public Works office and any future permit applications shall cost
the applicant three times the current permit or tapping charge.
(1984 Code Sec. 50.02)
927.03 EXTENSION OF WATER AND SEWER TOGETHER.
        No extension of water shall be made unless a sanitary sewer is extended
at the same time nor shall a sanitary sewer be extended without a similar
extension of water.
(1984 Code Sec. 50.03)
927.04 WHERE SEWER CONNECTION REQUIRED.
         All new houses or buildings or additions thereto, erected or
constructed within the City, shall be connected to the sanitary sewer system of
the City. This section shall not apply to any area where it would not be
economically feasible from an engineering standard to extend the sewer. The
feasibility of the extension shall be determined by the City Engineer.
(1984 Code Sec. 50.04)
927.05 TYING INTO WATER MAINS; COST.
         (a)    Any property owner desiring to tie into a water main running in
front of or adjacent to his property shall pay to the Director of Finance the
prorated cost that the property owner would have had to pay had he made the
tie-in at the time the water line was extended originally.
         (b)    The Director shall refund to the party originally paying for
the extension of the water main the sum so collected from the property owner
who ties into the water at a later date.
         (c)    The prorated share of tying into the water main shall be
computed by the Engineer of the City.
         (d)    New metered water services for new construction shall have an
outside register.
(1984 Code Sec. 50.05)
 OPENING OF STREET FOR INSTALLATION OR REPAIR OF MAINS
927.06 OBTAINING PERMIT AND POSTING SECURITY WHEN SURFACE OF RIGHT OF WAY IS
OPENED.
         (a)    Any person or legal entity requesting or causing the surface of
any public right of way in the City to be opened or excavated for the purpose
of installing, repairing or connecting to a public utility line shall be
required to obtain a permit and post a cashier’s check or a performance bond
for the amount so determined by the City Engineer to assure that the public
right of way will be restored per City Construction Standard 1167.16 as
determined by the City Engineer. Restoration of the public right of way per the
City Construction Standard shall be done at the expense of the person or legal
entity applying for the permit. Such check or bond shall be held by the City
for a period of up to one year and shall then be released should the Engineer
find that the repair has been satisfactorily completed.
   (b)   In addition, any person or legal entity requesting or causing the
surface of any public right of way in the City to be opened or excavated for
the purpose of installing, repairing or connecting to a public utility line
shall pay an inspection fee to the Finance Director, prior to the opening or
excavation. The inspection fee will be established by the Board of Control. The
person or legal entity shall hold the City harmless in matters related to the
opening or excavation.
   (c)   If any person or legal entity needs to perform an emergency street
opening to repair a public utility line, and there is not sufficient time to
obtain a permit, the person or legal entity may perform the street opening then
provide notice to the City Engineer before the close of the next business day.
This does not relieve the person or legal entity from the other requirements of
this section.
(Ord. 4292. Passed 4-28-09.)
927.07 STREET REPAIR FUND.
         In each case where a payment is made as provided in Section
927.06, the payment shall be placed by the Director of Finance in the Street
Repair Fund. Funds from the Street Repair Fund shall be used to defray the
expense of opening the surface of any street or alley and of restoring the
surface to its proper condition and grade.
(1984 Code Sec. 50.11)
927.08 RESTORATION OF SURFACE.
         (a)   When a person or legal entity causes the surface of any public
right of way in the City to be opened or excavated for the purpose of
installing, repairing or connecting to a public utility line, the person or
legal entity shall restore the public right of way per City Construction
Standard 1167.16. The restoration of the public right of way shall be completed
satisfactorily within thirty days of opening or excavating the public right of
way. An extension may be granted by the City Engineer for weather conditions,
construction, or other approved delays.
   (b)   When the restoration is not completed within the permitted time, or
when the restoration is completed but not completed per the Construction
Standards, the City has the authority to restore the public right of way per
the Construction Standards and recover the expenses from the cashier’s check or
performance bond. When the City must restore the public right of way, the City
may charge an administrative fee, as determined by the Board of Control, to
recover the administrative expense of the City’s involvement in restoring the
public right of way. (Ord. 4292. Passed 4-28-09.)
927.99 PENALTY.
         (a)    Any person or legal entity, either as owner, agent or occupant,
who violates any provision of this chapter is guilty of a misdemeanor of the
first degree for each offense, and each day during which any violation
continues shall constitute a separate offense.
   (b)   Any person or legal entity violating any provision of this chapter by
making, or causing to be made, an opening in any street or alley in the City,
or making, or causing to be made, a connection to or with either the water or
sewer mains in the City, without having first made payment to the Director of
Finance of the charge for each connection or repair to lines as set forth in
the foregoing sections shall be guilty of a misdemeanor of the first degree for
each offense. (Ord. 4292. Passed 4-28-09.)
CHAPTER 929
Stormwater Utility
929.01   Creation of stormwater utility.
929.02   Definitions and determinations.
929.03   Utility fee and collection.
929.04   Stormwater Review Committee.
929.01 CREATION OF STORMWATER UTILITY.
   The stormwater infrastructure system of the City, including all existing and
future stormwater drainage infrastructure, is determined to be a public
utility. A stormwater utility fee shall be collected for the operation,
construction, maintenance and repair of stormwater facilities; stormwater
system planning; and surface water quality management. The Director of Finance
shall establish the utility as an enterprise fund in the City’s budget, with no
more than thirty percent (30%) of the fund revenues allocated to operations and
the balance allocated to capital. This fund may incur debt to cover capital
outlays.
(Ord. 4539-21. Passed 6-16-21.)
929.02 DEFINITIONS AND DETERMINATIONS.
   (a)   The City Engineer and City Wastewater Superintendent shall jointly be
responsible for oversight of the Stormwater Utility System, or "System" which
includes all manmade facilities, structures and natural watercourses used for
collecting and conducting stormwater to, through and from drainage areas to the
points of final outlet including, but not limited to, any and all of the
following: conduits and appurtenant features, canals, creeks, channels, catch
basins, detention ponds, ditches, streams, gulches, gullies, flumes, culverts,
siphons, streets, curbs, gutters, dams, floodwalls, levees and pumping
stations.
   (b)   All elements of the System which provide for the collection and
disposal of stormwater and regulation of groundwater benefit and provide
services to all property within the incorporated City limits, including
property not presently served by the stormwater elements of the System. The
beneficiaries of the System include the owners and occupants of all real
properties within the City of Urbana which benefit by the provision, operation
and improvement of the System. Such benefits may include, but are not limited
to, the provision of adequate systems of collection, conveyance, detention, and
release of stormwater, the reduction of hazard to property and life resulting
from stormwater runoff, improvement in general health and welfare
through reduction of undesirable stormwater conditions, and improvement to the
water quality in
the storm and surface water system and its receiving waters.
   (c)   Floods from stormwater runoff may occasionally occur which exceed the
capacity of the System. This chapter does not imply that property subject to
the utility fee will always be free from stormwater flooding or flood damage,
or that the System shall ever be capable of handling all storm events; nor does
this Chapter create a liability on the part of, or cause of action against, the
City or its personnel for any flood damage; nor does it reduce the need or the
necessity for obtaining flood insurance.
   (d)   City personnel, in implementing the utility and administering the
System, have power to:
      (1)   Adopt procedures as required to implement these regulations as well
as take action to protect and maintain water quality within the System in
compliance with water quality standards established by state, regional and/or
federal agencies as now in effect, or hereafter amended;
      (2)   Administer the acquisition, design, construction, maintenance and
operation of the System, including capital improvements;
      (3)   Administer and enforce this chapter and all regulations and
procedures adopted relating to the design, construction, maintenance, operation
and alteration of the System including, but not limited to, the quantity,
quality and/or velocity of stormwater conveyed;
      (4)   Inspect private systems as necessary to determine the compliance of
such systems with this chapter and any regulations adopted pursuant to this
chapter;
      (5)   Prepare and revise a comprehensive drainage plan;
      (6)   Review plans, approve or deny, inspect and accept extensions to the
System;
      (7)   Analyze the cost of services and benefits provided, and the system
and structure of fees, charges, fines and other revenues of the System
annually, with a report available to City Council and the Stormwater Review
Committee upon request.
         (Ord. 4466-16. Passed 1-18-17.)
929.03 UTILITY FEE AND COLLECTION.
   (a)   The Director of Finance shall add a flat rate of five dollars ($5.00)
per month per meter for storm water utility services and infrastructure to all
utility bills, regardless of location. The rate shall change to five dollars
and fifty cents ($5.50) on March 1, 2022, first payable on the April 2022
utility bill, and be effective until otherwise changed.
(Ord. 4539-21. Passed 6-16-21.)
   (b)   Collection shall commence with billing for the month subsequent to the
effective date of Ordinance 4466-16.
   (c)    Any delinquent stormwater utility service charges which remain unpaid
for more than thirty days shall be assessed against the real property in the
same manner as other City utilities and shall be a lien against such property
collectible in the same manner as other utility assessments. It shall be the
duty of any persons purchasing any property to ascertain all unpaid stormwater
utility service charges outstanding against the property and pay upon request
for establishment of any other City utility service.
   (d)   This charge is deemed reasonable and necessary to pay for repair,
replacement, improvement, operation, regulation and maintenance of existing and
future City stormwater infrastructure.
(Ord. 4466-16. Passed 1-18-17.)
929.04 STORMWATER REVIEW COMMITTEE.
   The Stormwater Review Committee is hereby established to convene every five
years, starting in 2021, for a 45-day term to review the utility structure and
rates, and make recommendations to City Council for any changes, with no
increase of more than 10 percent above the base rate from any prior five year
term. At least one City Council member shall serve on the committee ex officio.
The City Engineer and City Wastewater Superintendent shall serve as members
along with at least seven individuals representing the interests of City
residents, business/industry, nonprofit organizations and other government
entities. The Committee shall meet at least twice, with a meeting schedule
established at the discretion of the City Engineer and City Wastewater
Superintendent. All meetings shall be open to the public pursuant to Urbana
Codified Ordinance
107.01 . The Committee shall submit a written report with recommendations to
Council by the end of the term, unless City personnel specify a need to extend
that term for good cause shown, such as pending action or new regulations
issued by the Ohio Environmental Protection Agency or U.S. Environmental
Protection Agency.
(Ord. 4466-16. Passed 1-18-17.)
